rationale:
Malaclemys terrapin is assessed as Vulnerable due to observed threats documented in the past and projected into the future with ≥35% population declines of monitored populations resulting from overexploitation, accidental mortality as bycatch in commercial Blue Crab fisheries, coastal habitat loss due to development, principally the loss of limited nesting habitat, in addition to extensive estuarine saltmarsh loss, and ongoing subsidized nest predation by mesopredators (threats reviewed in Roosenburg 2004; Butler et al. 2018; Chambers and Maerz 2018; Roosenburg and Kennedy 2018). Overall, it is our assessment that M. terrapin has sustained range-wide population declines over the last 30 years (two generations) of 25-30% and that the rate of decline is predicted to continue at the same rate for another 15 years (one generation), or about a 10-15% further decline, for a total decline over three generations (45 years) of 35-45%. The species therefore meets the criteria for Vulnerable designation under criteria A4acde. Malaclemys terrapin was last assessed in 1996, when it was evaluated as Near Threatened.

Documenting population declines for a long-lived species like M. terrapin is challenging and requires intensive, long-term sampling (Tucker et al. 2001). Female terrapins become sexually mature at 4-13 years and longevity may exceed 50 years. Using an average estimated generation time of 15 years, it is reasonable to examine trends in the terrapin population for the past 30 years (two generations) and project 15 years (one generation) into the future. Subpopulations for which long-term data are available show significant declines, upwards to 75% decrease in population size over 20 years in the two populations with long term data in South Carolina (Gibbons et al. 2001; Dorcas et al. 2007), Maryland (W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data), and 55% decline in a New York population over 20 years (R.L. Burke, unpubl. data). Other populations have high mortality rates due to anthropogenic causes (Wood and Herlands 1997; Avissar 2006; Szerlag and McRobert 2006; Crawford et al. 2013a,b; Maerz et al. 2018) and, in some cases, a change in population structure has been observed (Roosenburg et al. 1997; Wolak et al. 2010). It is not possible to determine range-wide population declines over specific time periods other than to rely on anecdotal evidence suggesting that terrapins are now rarely encountered in areas where they were once relatively common (Kennedy 2018a,b).
habitat:
Malaclemys terrapin is found in brackish coastal waters (salinity range = 0 to 35). Typical habitats include coastal regions, estuaries, lagoons, tidal creeks, mangrove swamps, and salt marshes. In coastal estuaries supporting large watersheds, terrapins can occur far inland up to the terminal end of the salt wedge (e.g., Chesapeake Bay, Hudson River, and Pamlico Sound). Although M. terrapin is found in brackish water, periodic access to freshwater is necessary for long-term health, and populations in high salinity habitats actively seek and drink freshwater which is essential for neonate survival and growth (Dunson 1985; Holliday et al. 2009) and may be a contributing factor to the semi-terrestrial behavior of neonates to 3-year-olds. Hatchlings are exceptionally desiccation tolerant (Figueras et al. 2018).

The diet of M. terrapin consists largely of invertebrates, crustaceans, and mollusks (Tucker et al. 1995, 2018) and a variety of plant materials and algae (Tulipani 2015; Erazmus et al. 2018). In some populations terrapins are predators of the Salt Marsh Periwinkle (Littoraria irrorata), a snail that grazes on epiphytes that grow on Salt Marsh Cord Grass (Spartina alterniflora). Silliman and Bertness (2002) demonstrated through a series of experiments that when periwinkle predators were removed, periwinkles damage and kill cord grass, leaving a barren mudflat and increasing marsh erosion rates. Although terrapins were not removed or tested in this experiment, as a periwinkle predator they are frequently identified as a potential saltmarsh keystone species. This extrapolation suggests that healthy terrapin populations play a role in maintaining primary production in salt marsh ecosystems and stabilizing shoreline vegetation, thus reducing local erosion.

Malaclemys terrapin exhibits considerable variation in size, sexual size dimorphism, and reproductive output throughout its range. In general, along the Atlantic sea board there is a gradient of increasing body size, greater sexual dimorphism, later ages of maturity, and higher reproductive output with increasing latitude (Lovich et al. 2018). Gulf Coast populations do not conform to this latitudinal variation and are larger than their counterparts on the Atlantic Coast at the same latitude. Most comprehensive life history data come from long-term studies of populations in South Carolina, Maryland, and New York, with limited data from other parts of the range focused mostly on reproductive output and females. Nonetheless, the differences in morphological and life history traits contribute to different environmental stressors and management strategies relevant to terrapin populations throughout the range. Careful modeling is needed to compare reproductive traits among populations to assess how total annual reproductive output per individual varies along the latitudinal gradient.

Diamondback Terrapins under natural conditions exhibit high adult survivorship, low reproductive rates, and high egg/juvenile mortality characteristic of most temperate turtles (Mitro 2003). As a consequence of this suite of life history traits, increases in adult mortality result in declining populations (Congdon et al. 1993, 1994). Marked variation in life history traits can be attributed to a broad latitudinal distribution (Lovich et al. 2018). Females from northern populations mature later and at a relatively larger size than those from southern populations. Clutch size and body size appear to be somewhat correlated over the range; females from New York average 12.8 eggs per clutch (Burke et al. 2018), Maryland females may produce as many as 26 eggs per clutch (W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data), and smaller females from more southern populations produce only 4–6 eggs per clutch (Seigel 1984). Average annual reproductive output depends on the number of clutches produced per season. In Chesapeake Bay populations, the average female may produce 1–3 clutches of about 13 eggs in a single nesting season (13–40 eggs/year) and detailed nesting data suggest that terrapins rarely forgo nesting annually, but the number of clutches per year may vary (Roosenburg and Dunham 1997). For detailed reviews of reproductive data, see Roosenburg (1994), Butler et al. (2006a, 2006b), Brennessel (2006), Ernst and Lovich (2009), and Lovich et al. (2018).

Malaclemys terrapin demonstrates marked sexual dimorphism, most likely as a fecundity advantage (Carr 1952), with females being considerably larger, with maximum reported population mean female carapace length of 20.1 cm and male carapace length of 13.3 cm (reviewed in Lovich et al. 2018). Female terrapins can reach weights over 2.5 kg in northern populations, but males rarely exceed 0.5 kg throughout the range (W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data). The maximum recorded size for an adult female, 32 cm carapace length, is much greater than that of males, 16 cm, from the same population, and the discrepancy between male and female size increases with latitude (W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data). Female terrapins mature later and at a larger size than males. The resulting difference in body size is more pronounced in more northern populations. Size differences result in differences in jaw morphology and bite forces that likely contribute to resource partitioning (diet, habitat) between the sexes (Tucker et al. 1995; Roosenburg et al. 1999; Herrel et al. 2018). Throughout their geographic range, population means for hatchlings range from 25–38 mm in carapace length and 6.3–8.8 g in mass (reviewed in Lovich et al. 2018). Maturity is reached at 4–13 years of age in females, and 2–7 years in males, depending on location (see summary in Brennessel 2006). Longevity may be greater than 40 years for some individuals; marked adult females have been recaptured 30 years after their initial capture as adults (R.C. Wood, unpubl. data; W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data). Generation time has not been reported in the published literature; available information indicates that it ranges from 13 to 20 years and also increases with increasing latitude (Mitro 2003; W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data). Generation times in more southern populations are shorter, as maturity at lower latitudes is attained several years earlier (Lovich et al. 2018).

Nesting requirements vary among subpopulations (Roosenburg 1994, Butler et al. 2018). Malaclemys terrapin embryos have temperature-dependent sex determination (TSD), with females produced at higher incubation temperatures, generating important differences between populations (Jeyasuria et al. 1994; Burke and Calichio 2014). The challenges of climate change, combined with sea level rise and nesting habitat loss (Michener et al. 1997, Woodland et al. 2017) could potentially affect sex ratios in populations. The conservation challenges associated with climate change and TSD as it affects sex ratios generates new concerns for the effective management of terrapin populations throughout their range, particularly when integrated with the nesting habitat loss due to development (Seigel and Gibbons 1995).

Terrapin hatchlings in northern parts of the range also facultatively overwinter in the nest, suggesting that the nesting environment is critical habitat throughout the entire year (Baker et al. 2006, 2018; Graham 2009; Kitson 2016). Post-emergence neonate habitat is poorly known, but after emergence, some hatchlings move to shallow, self-excavated hibernacula in upland areas (Draud et al. 2004, Duncan and Burke 2016) before moving into intertidal marshes where they may remain semi-terrestrial well into their second growing season (Muldoon and Burke 2012). Adult terrapins hibernate communally in depressions in the mud at the bottom of tidal creeks and embayments protected from prevailing weather (Haramis et al. 2011), in undercut banks within the tidal zone, or burrow into creek banks (Yearicks et al. 1981). Southern subspecies (e.g., M. t. rhizophorarum) may be active throughout the winter.
threats:
Four main factors pose the most significant threats to Malaclemys terrapin populations: 1) mortality of juveniles and adults in crab pots and mostly nesting females on roads, 2) loss of nesting and juvenile habitat to development and sea level rise, 3) the effect of subsidized predators at nesting beaches (Roosenburg 1991; Siegel and Gibbons 1995; Feinberg and Burke 2003; Woodland et al. 2017), and 4) loss of estuarine saltmarsh and mangrove habitats throughout their range (Kennish 2001; Ner and Burke 2008; Gedan et al. 2009).

In states with a commercial Blue Crab (Callinectes sapidus) fishery, which includes almost the terrapin’s entire range, incidental drowning in crab pots is considered to be the major threat to M. terrapin (Butler et al. 2006; Chambers and Maerz 2018). Terrapins, attracted to the bait, enter through an underwater opening, become trapped, and drown within a few hours (Wood 1997; Roosenburg 2004; Baker et al. 2013; Chambers and Maerz 2018). Small males and juveniles are caught more frequently than adult females due to the limitations on the size of the trap entrance. Wolak et al. (2010) suggested that high mortality in crab traps has led to selection on body size traits in a Chesapeake Bay population. Most studied populations where terrapins occurred with crab pots have skewed sex ratio biased toward females that have lower catch rates because of their larger size (Chambers and Maerz 2018). Crab pots remain the most prominent threat to terrapin populations and their ubiquitous use throughout the terrapin’s range and habitat hamper other conservation restoration efforts because the mortality caused by crab pots is so high.

Adult female terrapins are frequently struck and killed by motor vehicles while attempting to cross roads and motorways in search of nesting sites (Wood and Herlands 1997; Szerlag and McRobert 2006; Grosse et al. 2011; Crawford et al. 2013a,b; Maerz et al. 2018). Hatchling terrapins migrate to water after emerging from the nest and can get trapped in vehicular tire tracks left in the sand on nesting beaches. If the hatchlings are unable to escape, they may die of dehydration or be crushed by the next vehicle. Large female terrapins often bear scars from the propellers of motor boats; in the Chesapeake Bay region and in Jamaica Bay, New York, boat impacts are a significant source of mortality for this age class in areas with moderate to high boat traffic (Roosenburg 1991; R.L. Burke and Roe, unpubl. data).

Although most states now have legislation that regulates the collection of M. terrapin (Hackney 2010; Nanjappa and Conrad 2011; Kennedy 2018a), this species is still taken commercially in parts of Louisiana. Commercial interest in terrapins remains high, primarily for trade and consumption in Asia or to Asian communities in North America. Hatchlings sell in pet markets of Hong Kong for $50-500 each depending on colouration (T. Leuteritz, pers. comm.). In 2006, the last year in which terrapins were legally harvested in Maryland, watermen reported a catch of 10,500 pounds of terrapins. Additionally, harvest of terrapins for turtle farms in the US and Asia is taxing wild populations and contributing to potential illegal harvest in states where they are currently protected. One such event resulted in the offtake of more than 3,000 females from a single population in New Jersey. Serendipitously, this event resulted in the closure of the commercial terrapin harvest in New Jersey.

One of the terrapin subspecies, M. t. rhizophorarum, is considered endemic and endangered in its restricted range in southern Florida. Unless examined by expert terrapin biologists familiar with all the subspecies, M. t. rhizophorarum could easily be traded unnoticed because of its similarity to the other subspecies. Similar to endangered map turtles, genus Graptemys, some of which also can only be recognized by experts, the trade of endangered terrapin subspecies is facilitated by the trade of the species in general. Furthermore, several states throughout the range have provided protected status to terrapins or restricted trade and harvest. These terrapins cannot be distinguished from terrapins that were collected from areas where they were legally harvested or from farm-produced individuals.

Habitat destruction poses a serious and ongoing threat to the species. The Diamondback Terrapin’s range is coincident with areas of dense human population (Ner and Burke 2008), and >50% of original estuarine saltmarsh habitat in terrapin range has been lost over the last century (Kennish 2001). Coastal development, particularly salt marsh draining and shoreline armoring for residential or agricultural purposes, increased use of coastal waterways for commercial and recreational purposes, and loss of sand dunes (important nesting habitat) contribute to habitat loss and degradation which negatively affects terrapins (Isdell et al. 2015). Coastal development is particularly problematic because it frequently destroys nesting beaches (Roosenburg 1991; Roosenburg and Place 1995). Three consequences of development for terrapins are: 1) higher concentration of nesting habitat in remaining areas resulting in greater predation rates of nests, 2) alteration of incubation conditions potentially affecting survivorship and gender because of temperature-dependent sex determination, and 3) increased predation on adult females. Additionally, sea level rise due to climate change may have a severe impact on diamondback terrapin habitat including loss of nesting habitat, but more seriously the elimination of critical juvenile salt marsh habitat. Recent GIS modeling based on predicted sea level rise suggests substantial habitat loss during the next 50-100 years in Chesapeake Bay (Woodland et al. 2017).

Human-subsidized predators (i.e., native or introduced animals whose populations prosper as a result of association with humans and human-altered habitats) are another threat to turtle populations (Boarman 1997). Studies across the range have identified (locally introduced) Raccoons (Procyon lotor), Skunks (Mephitis mephitis), Coyotes (Canis latrans), feral Hogs (Sus scrofa), and non-native Norway Rats (Rattus norvegicus) as major predators on the adults, juveniles, and eggs of M. terrapin, accounting for a nest predation rate of 92%, and emerging hatchling predation rate of up to 20% (Feinberg and Burke 2003; Draud et al. 2004; Muldoon and Burke 2012; Buzuleciu et al. 2016).

Finally, the impacts of various pollutants in heavily urbanized estuarine environments jeopardize terrapin populations. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), heavy metals and various insecticides and herbicides all potentially affect terrapins (Holliday et al. 2018). Many of these compounds have been discovered in terrapins and have been demonstrated to have deleterious effects on development, growth, and survival (Holliday et al. 2009; Holliday and Holliday 2011; Holliday et al. 2018). Microplastics, which are both pollutants themselves and synergists with other pollutants, were found in the feces of eight of eight terrapins tested in Jamaica Bay, New York (R.L. Burke, unpubl. data).
population:
In the early 1900s, populations of Malaclemys terrapin were in danger of extinction due to intense commercial harvest for human consumption (Hay 1917). Although pre-harvest population data are lacking, many populations had recovered to some extent by the late 20th century and M. terrapin was listed as Lower Risk/Near Threatened by the IUCN Red List in 1996 (Kennedy 2018b). However, data from long-term studies (Avissar 2006; Dorcas et al. 2007; Roosenburg 2004; Wood and Herlands 1997) suggest that many terrapin populations are again in decline. Effects that contribute to observed declines in well-studied subpopulations (ongoing habitat loss/degradation, crab pot mortality, subsidized nest predation, and road mortality) are ubiquitous and likely to have a similar effect throughout the terrapin’s range (Seigel and Gibbons 1995). Low recruitment due to high nest predation, juvenile and adult male mortality in crab pots and high adult female mortality from vehicle collisions and crab pots in southern populations are cause for alarm because population models suggest a stable population requires both modest recruitment and, most importantly, high adult survival (Roosenburg 2004; Mitro 2003).

In Kiawah, South Carolina, population estimates from a mark-recapture study of M. terrapin suggest a decline of 75% over the last two decades (Gibbons et al. 2001; Dorcas et al. 2007). High male and juvenile mortality rates in this population, likely due to incidental drowning in crab pots, result in an increase in the proportion of large females in the population (Dorcas et al. 2007). Similarly, crab pots have been suggested to cause female biased sex ratios (Roosenburg et al. 1997) and potentially driving the evolution of male body size (Wolak et al. 2010) in Chesapeake Bay. Similar levels of decline have been observed in the adult female population during a 20 year population study in the Patuxent River of Chesapeake Bay. Factors contributing to the decline in the Patuxent population include commercial harvest, bycatch mortality in commercial fisheries, an oil spill, and nesting habitat loss (W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data).

Commercial and recreational use of crab pots continues to be the major contributing factor to the population declines from New Jersey to Texas (Bishop 1983; Wood 1997; Roosenburg 2004; Dorcas et al. 2007; Seigel and Gibbons 1994; Chambers and Maerz 2018). Populations in Chesapeake Bay have female biased sex ratios due to the impact of crab pots (Wolak et al. 2010; Roosenburg et al. 1997) in addition to compensatory growth and changed size structure as a consequence of continued crab pot mortality (Wolak et al. 2010). Recent work has suggested that even a single crab pot in a tidal creek or local area can drive population declines (Lovich et al. 2018).

In estuaries near Tuckerton, New Jersey, road mortality contributed to a significant decline in the number of adult females over 13 years (Avissar 2006). This demographic shift was not attributed to crab pot mortality because the site is closed to crabbing; however, a decline in large females is consistent with the observation that road mortality of nesting females had increased (Avissar 2006; Szerlag and McRobert 2006). A long-term study on the Cape May Peninsula of southernmost New Jersey documented 4,020 road kills during a 7-year period (Wood and Herlands 1997). As of 2011, the total number of roadkills at this study site has surpassed 10,000 adult females (R.C. Wood, unpubl. data). The terrapin population decline during this time is unknown, but is likely substantial because the area also has a significant commercial and recreational crab fishery (Wood 1997). Similarly in Georgia, small tidal creeks impacted by commercial crabbing and nearby roads had reduced terrapin populations relative to creeks more isolated from these threats (Grosse et al. 2011).

New York’s largest terrapin populations inhabit the heavily-urbanized Jamaica Bay. Researchers observed over 2,000 nests on one island in this study area in 1998 (Feinberg and Burke 2003). Recruitment is low because annual nest predation rates, primarily by raccoons, vary from 92-100%. The number of nests laid per year declined 43% from 1999-2011 (Feinberg and Burke 2003; R.L. Burke, unpubl. data) and the nesting terrapin population has experienced a 55% decline from 1998 to 2017 (R.L. Burke and Roe, unpubl. data).

Little is known about terrapin populations along the Gulf Coast. Historical accounts suggest large populations once existed in this part of the range, but overexploitation has reduced populations which are slow to recover in the face of heavy crabbing pressure (Coleman et al. 2011, 2014). Dauphine Island, Alabama, formerly supported a significant terrapin fishery which currently remains as a relic population (Coleman et al. 2014). Recent studies in Louisiana have discovered subpopulations in the Rockefeller National Wildlife Refuge and its adjoining bayous and in Barataria Bay, but detailed population and life history data are lacking from this area (Selman et al. 2014, Pearson and Wiebe 2018). Small populations are also known from Galveston Bay, Texas, but the combination of development and pollution has reduced the available habitat to a few small islands within the bay (V. Guillory, pers. comm.).

Bermuda’s terrapin population is estimated at about 100 individuals and recruitment is low, caused by low nest success (Outerbridge 2014). The reasons for developmental failure are not known, but could be due to insecticides and herbicides used around the only wetland where terrapins are found (M.E. Outerbridge, pers. comm.).
range:
Malaclemys terrapin inhabits the estuarine coastal waters of the United States along the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, from Cape Cod, Massachusetts to Corpus Christi, Texas (Iverson 1992; TTWG 2017). A breeding subpopulation also is found in the Bermuda Islands (Davenport et al. 2005), which was considered native by Parham et al. (2008) and genetically attributed to subspecies M. t. centrata. The human role in the origin of the Bermuda subpopulation remains under consideration (Lovich and Hart 2018), but it currently is an established and protected population (Outerbridge 2014).

Subspecific distributional information for the morphologically-defined historically recognized subspecies is as follows (noting, however, that molecular phylogeography does not agree with this pattern, but that a revised taxonomy has not yet been formulated; see Taxonomy section):

M. terrapin terrapin: from Cape Cod, Massachusetts southward to the vicinity of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, where it intergrades with M. terrapin centrata.

M. terrapin centrata: from the vicinity of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina southward to northern peninsular Florida, where it meets and intergrades with M. terrapin tequesta; also on Bermuda.

M. terrapin tequesta: Atlantic east coast of peninsular Florida to Biscayne Bay, where it intergrades with M. terrapin rhizophorarum.

M. terrapin rhizophorarum: Florida Keys westward to the Marquesas Keys.

M. terrapin macrospilota: Gulf coast of peninsular Florida, intergrading with M. terrapin pileata in the panhandle and with M. terrapin rhizophorarum in Florida Bay.

M. terrapin pileata: from the Florida panhandle, where it intergrades with M. terrapin macrospilota, to Louisiana, where it intergrades with M. terrapin littoralis.

M. terrapin littoralis: western Louisiana and the coast of Texas, at least as far south as Corpus Christi Bay.

Anecdotal reports that this species is found in Mexican waters (e.g., Carr 1952) have been disputed (Smith and Smith 1979); there is no credible information indicating occurrence in Mexico (Iverson 1992; Mexican Red List Workshop participants, Sept. 2005).

Range Size: The presence of a coastal species like M. terrapin is difficult to determine because of their cryptic nature and the inaccessibility of much of their habitat. Its distribution is discontinuous along the ~5,000 km of coastline between Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and Corpus Christi, Texas. However, it is unknown if the discontinuity can be attributed to natural biological boundaries or to barriers created by extensive urbanization and industrial development in portions of its coastal habitat. Terrapins inhabit salt marshes that form on the bay side of barrier islands, and the extent to which they move inland via estuaries varies considerably, but seems to be bounded by waters that are brackish for most of the year.  Nonetheless, terrapin habitat, salt marsh juvenile habitat, and nesting areas, have all diminished greatly because of salt marsh loss and the development of coastal and estuarine waterfront (Kennish 2001; Ner and Burke 2008). No range-wide population estimate is available, but data are consistent in that subpopulations are local, sensitive to anthropogenic perturbation, and many individually studied subpopulations are small, while others are more robust (summarized in Roosenburg and Kennedy 2018).
useTrade:
Malaclemys terrapin was utilized for food prior to European settlement in North America; however, as human populations increased throughout the terrapin’s range and terrapin consumption became fashionable, the exploitation reached unsustainable levels. By the late 19th century native populations were in dramatic decline, warranting the first federal attempts to farm terrapins (Kennedy 2018a). Captive propagation for commercial purposes was initiated in the early 20th century because of range-wide population declines and danger of extinction, indicating that fisheries of wild populations were not sustainable (Hay 1917). Extensive data are available for artificial propagation of terrapins for commercial purposes (Hay 1917; Coker 1920; Hildebrand and Hatsel 1926; Hildebrand 1932) but the general consensus of these studies was that it is not economically feasible to farm terrapins as a food source because of slow growth rates. The demand for terrapin meat eventually decreased and the depleted populations began to slowly recover after 1930 (Carr 1952). In the early 2000s increases in the commercial capture and trade of terrapins were identified (USDA 2011). Most of the captured turtles were shipped to Asian communities in major metropolitan areas in the US and also exported to Asia. This increase in demand alarmed turtle biologists and prompted many states to increase regulations, protection, and monitoring of terrapin populations (Kennedy 2018a). The primary concern with the resurgence of the commercial terrapin fishery is that, combined with habitat degradation, recovery will be slower, if not impossible. Export data for terrapins in 1999-2010 indicate an increase in the number of individuals and shipments, primarily as exports to Asia (USDA 2011). Concern about the increases in terrapin export has resulted in the closure of the remaining commercial wild harvest in all states except Louisiana. Maryland closed their commercial fishery, based primarily on the export to China and declining populations in Chesapeake Bay (Roosenburg et al. 2008). Following the closure of the Maryland fishery exports dropped by approximately 25% from their peak and most exports at this time are believed to originate from farms, although this has not been confirmed. Today, Louisiana remains the only state where terrapins can be harvested from the wild for commercial sale. Many states maintain a subsistence harvest of two per day for either consumption or pets.

Terrapins are currently bred in captivity (turtle farms) on a small scale in the United States and the hatchlings are sold commercially for the pet trade and to supply aquaculture rearing facilities in Asia that eventually supply the consumption trade and maintain reproductive colonies for the pet trade. Recent exports of high numbers of terrapin hatchlings originating from the single commercial turtle farm in Maryland revealed that successful terrapin farming requires a constant infusion of wild brood stock. The adults that produced most of the hatchlings sold were obtained from New Jersey in a manner that was disputably legal or illegal; New Jersey subsequently closed its commercial terrapin fishery (T. Leuteritz, pers. comm.).
conservationActions:
Diamondback Terrapins are protected from commercial exploitation in most states where they occur, but as of early 2018 commercial harvests remain permitted under regulations in Louisiana (Kennedy, 2018a). Personal possession is permitted under certain conditions in most states (Nanjappa and Conrad 2011; Kennedy, 2018a) but restricted in most cases to no more than two individuals and permits required for possession as pets. Malaclemys terrapin was included in CITES Appendix II in 2013, making its international trade subject to determinations and evaluation that traded volumes are not detrimental to the survival of wild populations.

Hackney (2010) used the standardized Natural Heritage Program to compare the conservation status of terrapins among range states. Of the 16 range states, one (Rhode Island) lists the species as S1, or critically imperiled. Four states list the species as S2, imperiled, while six states list it as S3, vulnerable. Four states consider the diamondback terrapin to be S4, apparently secure. South Carolina has not ranked terrapins according to this scale. State protective listing or harvest regulation in all range states is recommended. In Bermuda, diamondback terrapins have level 2 protection under the Protected Species Order 2012.

Diamondback Terrapins reside in coastal habitats that are intensively used and modified by humans (Kennish 2001, Ner and Burke 2008, Gedan et al. 2009). Safeguarding areas of optimal habitat, particularly foraging, nesting and hibernation sites, from development and other modification is essential for the long-term survival of this species. Terrapins occur in a substantial number of protected areas and their movement is limited (Converse et al. 2015). Mortality in crab pots and habitat fragmentation are suggested to reduce gene flow while signatures of the past commercial trade and movement of terrapins are still detectable in some populations (Converse et al. 2017, Converse and Kuchta, 2018). Terrapins use a variety of estuarine habitats throughout their range and local populations effectively exploit their native habitat. Populations can grow and respond quickly when provided with predator-free nesting areas, high quality juvenile habitat, and protection of adults, in particular reproductive females (Roosenburg et al. 2014, R.L. Burke, unpubl. data), suggesting that estuarine or marine preserves combined with nest predator control can provide an effective tool to restore terrapin populations in areas where numbers are reduced (Roosenburg 2018).

Bycatch reduction devices (BRD) can greatly reduce the number of terrapins that drown in crab traps (Wood 1997; Hoyle and Gibbons 2000; Roosenburg and Green 2000; Butler and Heinrich 2007). By installing BRDs in crab pots, most adult female terrapins are excluded, particular in mid-Atlantic, Northeast Atlantic, and the Gulf coast regions where body sizes are larger. BRDs are also effective in southern Atlantic regions and Florida and perhaps more important because adult females never outgrow the vulnerability to crab pots without BRDs (Grosse et al. 2011). Several states now require BRDs; however, regulations vary considerably across the terrapin’s range (Hackney 2010), as does the intensity of enforcement of regulations. Broad adoption of BRDs will significantly assist the species' prospects (Guillory and Prejean 1998; Rook et al. 2010; Radzio et al. 2013). Perhaps the greatest concern for terrapins is entrapment in derelict or ghost crab pots that are not regularly checked. Several cases have been recorded where >20 individuals have been recovered dead from crab pots that were abandoned, one with more than 100 individuals (Bishop 1983; Roosenburg 1991; Grosse et al. 2011).

Since 2003, research scientists and summer interns at The Wetlands Institute in New Jersey have deployed barrier fencing to reduce road mortality in their study area. Results to date suggest that barrier fencing can be an effective terrapin conservation tool (McLaughlin et al. 2012). Similarly, at JFK Airport in New York, personnel successfully use barrier fencing to keep terrapins off runways (Burke and Francoeur 2014). Combined with nesting habitat improvement adjacent to roadways, fencing can dramatically reduce roadway mortality and help direct terrapins to protected nesting sites (Crawford et al. 2013a,b; Maerz et al. 2018). Finally, roadway warning signals activated at times of peak nesting in high use areas can dramatically reduce nesting female road mortality. Impacts by watercraft also present a problem for terrapins in areas with high boat traffic (Roosenburg 1991; Lester et al. 2013). Furthermore, terrapins appear not to respond to the noise of approaching vessels, increasing the risk of boat impact; thus suggesting that marine speed limits near areas of terrapin congregation (e.g., nesting beaches) would be the only effective mechanism to reduce boat strikes (Lester et al. 2014, 2018).

Nest protection and head-starting programs exist at a variety of locations, and are subject to active research on their effective contribution to population dynamics and establishment success (Herlands et al. 2004; Smeenk 2010; Petrov 2014; Roosenburg 2018). High nest predation remains a key conservation problem for terrapins and control of mammalian nest predators increases nest success (Munscher et al. 2012) and the complete absence of nest predators can contribute to population recovery (Roosenburg et al. 2014). Head-starting can supplement population growth and head-started individuals can establish within native populations. Furthermore, head-started females can become reproductive and some remain in the local population where they were released (Roosenburg 2018). However, the low level of gene flow among populations (Converse et al. 2015) suggests that source animals should only come from the same population they will supplement or from the nearest population for extirpated areas.

One example of effective terrapin conservation and restoration is the Paul S. Sarbanes Environmental Restoration Project at Poplar Island, Chesapeake Bay, Maryland (Roosenburg et al. 2014, Roosenburg 2018). Poplar Island’s restoration has established predator-free nesting habitat and extensive salt marsh habitat for juveniles. There also is an active head-starting program on Poplar Island. The terrapin population on Poplar Island is growing rapidly due primarily to the high nest survival (Roosenburg et al. 2014) and high quality juvenile habitat that ensures high post-hatching juvenile survivorship (Roosenburg 2018). Although head-starting does contribute to population growth, its impacts are secondary to that of the habitat creation and protection (W.M. Roosenburg, unpubl. data). The Poplar Island example illustrates the basic requirements for population recovery which suggests that estuarine reserves or sanctuaries that include both nesting and juvenile habitat, combined with nest predator control, offer an excellent strategy for terrapin population recovery.

Further research on terrapin conservation is needed, particularly towards understanding individual and seasonal movement patterns, habitat use at different life stages, and refinement of the taxonomy. Although some populations and areas are well studied, other parts of the range have less data, particularly the Gulf Coast and the populations within Pamlico Sound and the estuarine waters of North Carolina, and southern New England. Most states have some form of ongoing terrapin research, but the expansive range and the need for boats to access key habitats limits both surveys and detailed population studies. Recent work also has suggested that climate change will dramatically affect habitat availability for terrapins, particularly the juvenile dependence on saltmarsh habitat, which is predicted to decline dramatically due to sea level rise (Woodland et al. 2017). Further study of the effects of sea level rise is needed to evaluate how habitat and resources will be affected.

Although these conservation targets have been known for years, declines in terrapin populations have not been fully addressed for a variety of issues. Conservation measures, such as establishing requirements for bycatch reduction devices in crab pots, have often been effectively resisted by commercial fishermen through political lobbying efforts. Furthermore, even with regulations in place, lack of compliance and enforcement results in ineffective use rates (Radzio et al. 2014). Finally, conflicts between the preservation of nesting habitat shoreline and the development and protection of high-value coastal real estate seem to preempt terrapin conservation measures. Despite the slow pace of terrapin conservation, some progress has been made to reduce road mortality in some areas (Crawford et al. 2013a,b) and population recovery and growth have been observed in at least one population (Roosenburg et al. 2014). Additionally, the technology to reduce terrapin capture in crab pots has made substantial progress (Roosenburg 2004, Chambers and Maerz 2018) as range-wide fine-tuning of bycatch reduction devices (BRDs) continues (Schwenter and Arndt, unpubl. data).

rationale: Nilssonia formosa is listed as Critically Endangered because there has been an estimated 80% decline in the global population over the past three generations (estimated at a 90 year period). This is continuing in response to ongoing exploitation and habitat loss.
habitat: Nilssonia formosa is a highly aquatic turtle that is associated with large rivers with a sandy substrate. Eggs are laid on sandbanks in the river; about 20 eggs are laid in each clutch, it is not known how many clutches a female may lay in a year (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). Age of maturity of related species is about 10 years, it is therefore suggested that this species has a generation length of 30 years; the longevity is not known.
threats: Nilssonia formosa was traded in some numbers in the East Asian food trade, but is now infrequently encountered. Eggs are harvested by local people in Myanmar (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018). Additional important threats include: increased sedimentation and high boat traffic for rivers; illegal fishing (dynamite, electroshock, poison); continuing settlement by people in riverside habitats; and gold mining impacts. It is uncommon to rare in the wild, and has a life history particularly sensitive to exploitation of adults as it is slow-breeding.
population: Nilssonia formosa is a rare species that was formerly quite abundant. It is suspected that a minimum decline of 80% has occurred in the past three generations (equating to 90 years) and continuing into the future due to exploitation and habitat degradation.
range: Nilssonia formosa is endemic to Myanmar, where it is found in three main rivers: the Ayeyarwady River, the Chindwin River and the Sittaung River; it occurs throughout much of these rivers in low numbers. The species might range into Yunnan (China) although this is not confirmed. It has been recorded from sea level to about 200 m above sea level.
useTrade: Nilssonia formosa is collected for the domestic and international (East Asian) food trade.
conservationActions: Nilssonia formosa is listed in CITES Appendix II. The species is designated as Protected under Myanmar’s Protection of Wildlife, Wild Plants and Conservation of Natural Areas Law of 1994. There is a small population in Htamanthi Wildlife Sanctuary (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). Mandalay Zoo is breeding this species and has a number of hatchlings (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: Cyclemys fusca is listed as Least Concern, as although there is extensive trade in the species for the East Asian food market, there does not appear to be a marked decline in the population and the species remains widespread and common within Myanmar.
habitat: Cyclemys fusca can regularly be encountered in rocky streams (with boulders) within hill country. It can also be found on the forest floor, where it is typically associated with dry stream beds (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). The age of maturity is estimated to be about seven years, but longevity is not well known.
threats: Although there is a substantial trade in this turtle, the species doesn’t seem to be greatly impacted by harvesting and is still very common (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). It is likely to be affected to some degree by industrial and agricultural development, habitat modification and loss, collection, pollution, invasive species and climate change.
population: Cyclemys fusca is still common, and caught easily in forests by hunters. Its population is believed to be stable.
range: Cyclemys fusca is endemic to Myanmar, where it is widespread throughout much of the country in a wide variety of habitats. There are no records from Manipur and Nagaland in India, despite suggestions that the species might occur here (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). It can be found from ~175 to 1,000 m above sea level.
useTrade: Cyclemys fusca is perceived to be the most traded species from Myanmar, traded by truckloads for export into East Asia. This species is only consumed in small numbers within Myanmar (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018).
conservationActions: The genus Cyclemys was included in CITES  Appendix II in 2013. It is protected by national legislation in Myanmar, and populations are present in several protected areas (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: Chitra vandijki is listed as Critically Endangered, because there has been a decline estimated to be over 80% over the past three generations (largely through overharvesting), and continuing into the immediate future. This species is elusive and difficult to locate and so estimates of population are difficult.
habitat: Chitra vandijki is almost wholly aquatic and inhabits medium to large lowland rivers with sandbanks suitable for nesting (Platt et al. 2014). Little is known about the ecology of C. vandijki, but it’s congeners reportedly eat fish, molluscs, crabs and shrimp. In captivity they have been observed ambushing fish from a concealed position under sand (Pritchard 2001). Over 70 eggs have been found in a nest (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). Age at sexual maturity is approximately 10–15 years based on the maturity of other Chitra spp. and 30–45 years is estimated as a generation length. Longevity is unknown, but presumed to be long and could be over 100 years.
threats: Softshell turtles have long been consumed locally for subsistence. However, since the mid-1990s, international trade of live turtles into southern China has significantly increased. In addition to overexploitation, Chitra vandijki is likely impacted by gold mining activities within its limited range, and the use of explosives and poisons for fishing and habitat degradation along the Ayeyarwady and Chindwin rivers (Kuchling et al. 2004). Local fishermen often kill this species as it bites through fishing nets, and community engagement to protect this turtle is difficult (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018).
population: Almost no data are available regarding the population status of Chitra vandijki. However reports from local villagers and fishermen suggest that the species is “rare to very rare” along the Ayeyarwady River (van Dijk 1994). Interviews by Kuchling et al. (2004), on the other hand, suggest that C. vandijki is not as rare in the upper Chindwin and Nan Tha Let Rivers. It occurs from sea level to about 300 m above sea level. It is rare in the Salween River and the Sittaung River (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). An estimated population decline of more than 80% is suspected in the past three generations and continuing into the future as a result of exploitation and habitat degradation (Participants Singapore Red List Workshop 2018).
range: Chitra vandijki is endemic to Myanmar and confirmed records are available for the Ayeyarwady and Chindwin Rivers, and their tributaries (Platt et al. 2014), with more recent records from the Salween River and the Sittaung River (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018). It occurs below 300 m asl.
useTrade: Chitra vandijki is harvested for both domestic and international (East Asian) food markets.
conservationActions: Chitra vandijki is included in CITES Appendix II, and presumably is designated as Protected under Myanmar’s Protection of Wildlife, Wild Plants and Conservation of Natural Areas Law of 1994. However, enforcement of legislation is often lax and largely ineffectual in preventing trade from Myanmar to southern China (Platt et al. 2014). Chitra vandijki is known from the Htamanthi Wildlife Sanctuary and there are seven confiscated animals in a large pond in Htamanthi Village (K. Platt, pers. comm. 2018). Captive breeding of this species is difficult (K. Platt pers. comm. 2018)

rationale:
Peronedys anguillaris is endemic to Australia and is only known from South Australia and southern Western Australia (Recherche Archipelago). There have been seagrass habitat declines in parts of its range and various shallow seagrass habitats are subject to sedimentation from coastal runoff, effluent discharge and physical damage. Members of the family are viviparous, and therefore reproduce at a local, site-associated level, and have low dispersive ability, characteristics that can increase vulnerability to processes causing population decline. However, there are no specific data indicating population declines from habitat disturbance. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend research on this species' life history characteristics and monitoring of this species' habitat and population status.





.
habitat: Peronedys anguillaris inhabits seagrass areas, but has also been recorded in reef habitat (Hutchins 2005). It is known from among seagrass roots (Hoese et al. in Gomon et al. 1994), in calm bays and still estuaries (including mud-bottomed estuaries) and mud habitats. This species is viviparous (Neira et al. 1998).
threats: Protected bays associated with seagrass habitats appear critical to the survival of Eel-blenny (Pogonoski et al. 2002). In some of the areas where this species occurs, it is noted that seagrass habitat has suffered impacts, such as Nepean Bay on Kangaroo Island (Edyvane 1997, Gray 2000). Furthermore, various shallow seagrass habitats in Gulf St Vincent  and Spencer Gulf are subject to sedimentation from coastal runoff, effluent discharge, physical damage (dredging, channel development, boating etc) and other impacts that reduce the aerial extent and density of seagrass cover (Shepherd 1970; Hart 1996, 1997; Westphalen et al. 2005). However, there are no specific data on the potential impacts of such habitat loss upon populations of this species (Baker 2009).
population: There is no population information available for this species. It is known only from a few museum specimens (J.T. Williams and W. Holleman pers. comm. 2010).
range: Peronedys anguillaris is endemic to Australia and is known from South Australia and southern Western Australia (Recherche Archipelago) (Pogonoski et al. 2002, Hutchins 2005). The record from Moreton Bay (Queensland) (Gomon et al. 1994) is doubtful (Kuiter 1996a).
useTrade: Peronedys  anguillaris is listed on an international website for the aquarium trade (aquariumsite.org); however no trade information for this species is included on the site (Baker 2009).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale: Ophiclinus gabrieli is endemic to Australia and is relatively widespread from Kangaroo Island  in South Australia to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria. It inhabits a variety of habitats from seagrass areas, tidal rock pools, Cystophora macroalgae, sandy substrate with sparse Halophila seagrass cover and near rock outcrops. Possible threats from channel clearing/dredging and nearshore trawling may pose a threat to this species, however, specific data indicating population declines are lacking. Moreover, its distribution overlaps a number of marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of this species' habitat and status of its populations.
habitat: Ophiclinus gabrieli inhabits seagrass areas, commonly amongst blackened, dead, Amphibolis seagrass leaves, as occurs in Western Port Bay, Victoria (Kuiter 1993). In northern Tasmania, it has been collected from tidal rock pools. In South Australia, it has been recorded from Cystophora macroalgae, sandy substrate with sparse Halophila seagrass cover, near rock outcrops (with Pinna shells, turfing red algae and Sabellid worms) (Cheshire et al. 2002) and fine sandy substrate with sparse Caulerpa and turfing red algae (Fairhead et al. 2002).
threats: Channel clearing/dredging may pose a threat to populations of Frosted  Snake-blenny, which has been recorded from a number of nearshore areas  with heavy boating traffic and channel maintenance works such as  periodic dredging. Given that the species is benthic, has been recorded  in soft bottom habitats, and has limited mobility and localised  reproduction, then processes such as nearshore trawling may also pose a  threat to populations of Frosted Snake-blenny in some areas, however, specific data indicating population declines from habitat disturbance and nearshore trawling are lacking (Baker 2009).
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: Ophiclinus gabrieli is endemic to Australia and is known from Kangaroo Island, South Australia eastwards to northern Tasmania and Wilsons Promontory, Victoria.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale: Ophiclinus antarcticus is endemic to Australia and is relatively widespread from Western Australia to South Australia. It is found in a variety of habitats including nearshore rocks and submerged logs, jetties with decaying seagrass leaves, sandy bottom with shell grit, rubble, decaying seagrass leaves and macroalgae. This species may be impacted by channel clearing/dredging in shallow bays in South Australia, however, there is no information indicating population declines from habitat conversion and degradation. Its distribution overlaps a number of marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of this species' habitat and status of its populations.
habitat: Ophiclinus antarcticus has been recorded under nearshore rocks and submerged logs, commonly near jetties with decaying seagrass leaves (Kuiter 1996a). Divers have also recorded the species on sandy bottom with shell grit, rubble, decaying seagrass leaves, and coralline and other red macroalgae. In south-western W.A., this species has been recorded rarely on reefs in mainland bays, and in Israelite Bay (Hutchins 2005). To date, records are known from the shallowest subtidal (0m – 1m) to at least 18m (OZCAM 2010). It grows to 14cm (Hoese et al. in Gomon et al. 1994) or 17.5cm (Kuiter 1996a). Food items probably include amphipods (Kuiter 1996a).
threats: Channel clearing/dredging may pose a threat to populations of Adelaide Snake-blenny, which has been recorded from a number of shallow bays in South Australia, including areas with heavy boating traffic and channel maintenance works such as periodic dredging. Given that the species is benthic, in sand and rubble habitats (at least to 18m), and has limited mobility and localised reproduction, then processes such as prawn trawling may also pose a threat to populations of Adelaide Blenny in some areas, however, there is no information at present time indicating population declines from habitat conversion and degradation (Baker 2009).
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: Ophiclinus antarcticus is endemic to Australia and is found from Cockburn Sound in Western Australia to Kangaroo Island and Fleurieu Peninsula, South Australia (Hoese et al. in Gomon 1994; Kuiter 1996a; Hutchins 1994, 2005).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale: Kottelatlimia pristes is a freshwater species known from Indonesia, found within freshwater rivers and peat swamp forests of north Selangor blackwater peat swamp forest, rivers west of Sintang, Kalimantan Barat, and Sebangau tropical peat swamp forest. More data are needed on its population size and trend. The species distribution, although not meeting the threatened criteria thresholds, is at risk of rapid decline. All of these areas face great threats of deforestation, land conversion and, especially, peatland forest fires. Given this species is restricted within three to five locations, all of which may decline greatly in size with a single forest fire within them, this species faces a plausible future threat that could drive the taxon into Critically Endangered or Extinct in a very short time. Therefore, this species is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Kottelatlimia pristes is known to occur within freshwater rivers and peatland swamp forest systems (Ng et al. 1994, Beamish et al. 2003, Kottelat 2013, Husson et al. 2018). This species can grow to a length of 4.0 cm (SL male/unsexed; Kottelat et al. 1993). More research is required on the ecological role of this species.
threats: The main threat to Kottelatlimia pristes is habitat degradation from large scale, multi-purpose deforestation within peat swamp forests. Deforestation for agriculture, plantations and illegal logging has led to pollution from oil, increased nutrient loads, sedimentation and solid waste, in addition to large scale industrialisation, airports building and settlement-urbanisation (Ng and Shamsudin 2001, Chong et al. 2010). This causes ongoing peat drainage that results in peat subsidence and heightened dry-season fire risks (Harrison et al. 2009, Chisholm et al. 2016), as well as the loss of 1.8 Mha of peat swamp forests in Kalimantan, Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia from 2007 to 2015; equivalent to an annual deforestation rate of 4.1 % (Miettinen et al. 2016).
population: No data are available regarding the population size or trend of this species.
range: Kottelatlimia pristes is a freshwater species known from Indonesia and Malaysia. It occurs in Peninsular Malaysia and Kalimantan in freshwater rivers and peat swamp forests. This species has been found to occur within north Selangor blackwater peat swamp (Ng et al. 1994, Beamish et al. 2003), as well as rivers and swamps west of Sintang, Kalimantan Barat, Kalimantan (Kottelat 2013), and Sebangau tropical peat swamp forest (Husson et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is insufficient information regarding this species' possible use and or trade, and more research is required.
conservationActions: There is no information regarding conservation for this species and more research is needed for this species' population. The carbon payment scheme known as REDD+ (Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation plus conservation, sustainable management of forests, and enhancement of forest carbon; UNFCCC 2010) may help offset the opportunity costs of conserving peatland swamp forests  within Malaysia/Indonesia, thereby safeguarding its unique fish biota and carbon stocks. In May 2011, the president of the Republic of Indonesia decreed a two year moratorium on new permits for converting peat swamp forests as part of a bilateral REDD+ agreement with Norway. There are no population data known for this species and, given the high risk of population and habitat reduction with rapid peatland swamp fires (Harrison et al. 2009, Chisholm et al. 2016), it is recommended that further research is conducted to establish current population size and trend.

rationale: This restricted range species is known only from three locations where it has been collected from coral reef, seagrass, sponges, rocky cliffs and boulders on large patches of white sand between zero to 20 m depth. Its estimated EOO is 10,241 km2 and its AOO is 1,012 km2, which meets the thresholds for Vulnerable under B1 and B2. It may be impacted by degradation of coral habitat due to anchoring of super tankers in Saba Bank as well as a directly observed coral cover loss of 14.6% over a 41 year period (1970-2011) off St. Croix. It also may be susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish throughout its entire range, however, species-specific information is not yet known. Therefore, it is listed as VU B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii).
habitat: Specimens were collected from low coral and sponges on white sand bottom, off rocky cliffs, from boulders on large patches of white sand, and short seagrass at edge of sand patches (Greenfield 1993).
threats:
This species may be impacted by coral reef degradation. The Saba Bank area where it has been found is a locality where supertankers anchor and destroy coral reefs. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease. Location specific estimates in coral decline: no long-term data available for Saba Bank; 14.6% decline off St. Croix between 1970-2011; no data available for St. Barthelemy (Jackson et al. 2014). The area of total coral cover within its range is 47 km2, and St. Croix represents 19% of this area (9 km2). However, this species has been collected from other habitat types and is therefore not likely dependent on live coral reef. Coral habitat (47 km2) comprises 5% of its known extent between 0-20 m depth (1,012 km2).  

It may be threatened by the invasive lionfish, which is known to inhabit areas throughout its entire range. It is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. It has not yet been recorded from a lionfish gut analysis, however, 13 Gobiidae spp. have been documented. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This very rare species was previously known from only five specimens taken at Saint Barthelemy in 1965, one from Saba Bank (Williams et al. 2010) and one from St. Croix in 2001.
range: Psilotris boehlkei is known only from St. Croix (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2015), St. Barthelemy (Greenfield 1993), and Saba Bank Atoll (Williams et al. 2010) in the Caribbean Sea. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,241 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a zero to 20 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,012 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 20 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed into the distribution, habitats and ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Tigrigobius redimiculus is known only from patch reefs in the proximity of Veracruz, Mexico and Isla Lobos. As this species is not a live coral obligate, but may be relatively common where it occurs on live brain coral and coral rubble. Considering it is not a live coral obligate, its EOO and AOO is estimated as 11,861 and 1,606 km2, respectively. However, coral reef declined by at least 17% over a 34 year period off Veracruz and unquantified degradation is also occurring off Tuxpan-Lobos, which causes its total area of available live coral habitat to be calculated as 32 km2. Pollution and coastal development are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs in both locations. Given this information, it conservatively qualifies for Vulnerable under B1 and B2. It is likely susceptible to predation by the invasive Lionfish, which now occurs throughout its entire range. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific decline nor generation length are available at this time. Therefore, it is listed as VU B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii). Further research is needed on the impact of habitat degradation and lionfish predation.
habitat: Tigrigobius redimiculus is typically found on brightly illuminated surfaces of either living boulder brain coral (Colpophyllia natans) or algae encrusted covered coral remnants in shallow waters between three to eight metres depth near reefs (Taylor and Akins 2007). Its maximum size is 1.7 cm SL.
threats: Tigrigobius redimiculus is threatened by loss of coral reef habitat. It inhabits degraded coral reef systems, including dead coral and algae encrusted coral (L. Tornabene pers. comm. 2014), so live coral may not be crucial to the survival of this species. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). It is considered endemic to the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems which are threatened by heavy anthropogenic impacts such as accidental fuel spills from the nearby Port of Tuxpan, commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area, and contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants out of the Tuxpan River (Ortiz-Lozano 2012, Gandara et al. 2013). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). This species may be easily targeted for predation by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (Green et al. 2012).
population: Tigrigobius redimiculus is commonly observed.
range: Tigrigobius redimiculus is distributed in the western Atlantic on the western Gulf of Mexico Mexican reef systems from Isla De Lobos (21°29.36'N, 97°13.53'W) south to Isla Verde off Veracruz (19°11.88'N, 96°04.12'W) (Taylor and Akins 2007). A record of T. macrodon from Coatzacoalcos is likely a misidentification of T. redimiculus (L. Tornabene pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,409 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a coral reef layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 32 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). The Veracruz Reef System constitutes 22 km2 of its total range in the Gulf. Quantified data are not available for the Tuxpan-Lobos Reef System, however, declines are suspected there as well due to increased port activity and pollution from river runoff (Gandara et al. 2013). However, this may be an underestimate of its AOO as this species is not a live coral obligate. Given this uncertainty, a more conservative estimate of its EOO and AOO may be 11,861 and 1,606 km2, respectively (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 10 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO).
useTrade: Tigrigobius redimiculus is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano has been designated as a national park since 1992 and a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 2006, however, there is no effective management plan in place. Furthermore, the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There is also a marine protected area around Isla Lobos, with a management plan in press, but there is limited enforcement (T. Camarena-Luhrs pers. comm. 2014).

rationale: This species is endemic to the Gulf of Mexico where it is restricted to two Mexican reef systems: Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz, Mexico. It can be somewhat common and is dependent on coral reefs. Its estimated EOO is 8,409 km<sup>2 </sup>and its AOO is 32 km<sup>2</sup>. There has been a directly observed 17% decline in coral cover off Veracruz over a period of 34 years. Both reef locations are threatened by pollution and coastal development, which are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs. Given this information, it qualifies for Vulnerable under B1 and Endangered under B2. It is likely susceptible to predation by the invasive Lionfish, which now occurs throughout its entire range. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific decline is not available at this time. Therefore, it is listed as EN B2ab(iii). This species should be monitored as further loss of coral could quickly cause this species to qualify for CR.
habitat: Elacatinus jarocho can be found between three to 25 m depth on high profile coral reefs typically dominated by Montastrea cavernosa, M. annularis, Colpophyllia natans, and skeletal reef framework. This species and E. atronasus from the Bahamas are the only two in the genus that school in the water column. Small to large aggregations (12–60 individuals) are normally found close to the reef near high profile corals or overhangs. Such reef structure presumably provides shelter from direct sunlight because aggregations were usually observed in darker, shaded areas. Unlike E. atronasus, individuals of this species were never observed stationary on any substrate, but rather hovered continuously about five to 25 cm above the reef frequently in association with Coryphopterus hyalinus or C. personatus. It has not been observed to clean other species or interact in other symbiotic relationships. Small and large individuals coexisted in the same aggregations and did not display territorial or hierarchical behaviours (Taylor and Akins 2007). The recorded maximum size is 2.72 cm SL.
threats: Elacatinus jarocho is likely impacted by loss of coral reef habitat. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). It is considered endemic to the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems which are threatened by heavy anthropogenic impacts such as accidental fuel spills from the nearby Port of Tuxpan, commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area, and contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants out of the Tuxpan River (Ortiz-Lozano 2012, Gandara et al. 2013). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). This species may be easily targeted for predation by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (Green et al. 2012).
population: Elacatinus jarocho is relatively common. Small to large aggregations of 12-60 individuals are found near high profile coral overhangs.
range: Elacatinus jarocho is known only from the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico and may be present at reefs between these two areas. Specimens were observed as far north as Isla De Lobos and as far south as Anton Lizardo (Taylor and Akins 2007). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,409 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a coral reef layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 32 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). The Veracruz Reef System constitutes 22 km2 of its total range in the Gulf. Quantified data are not available for the Tuxpan-Lobos Reef System, however, declines are suspected there as well due to increased port activity and pollution from river runoff (Gandara et al. 2013).
useTrade: Elacatinus jarocho is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species is currently known only from within a protected area. More information is needed on population, habitat status and impact of major threats. The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano has been designated as a national park since 1992 and a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 2006, however, there is no effective management plan in place. Furthermore, the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There is also a marine protected area around Isla Lobos, with a management plan in press, but there is limited enforcement (T. Camarena-Luhrs pers. comm. 2014).

rationale:
This widely distributed species can be abundant where it occurs in coral reef habitat and is often associated with sponges. Its estimated global AOO is less than 2,000 km2 and is severely fragmented due to its preference for Montastrea annularis. In addition, the larval retention of this species is very localized and therefore, has a very low probability of reseeding depleted subpopulations. Given this information, it meets the threshold for Vulnerable under B2. It is threatened by the loss of coral reef habitat throughout its entire range (at least 20% over a 41 year period). It has been documented in the diet of the invasive lionfish, which may constitute a further threat to its population, however, further research is needed as cleaner gobies are generally not considered preferred lionfish prey items. Therefore, it is listed as VU B2ab(iii) globally.

In the Gulf of Mexico, its AOO is 25 km2 and its EOO is 2,915 km2. Its separate subpopulation in the Gulf of Mexico off Veracruz is threatened by pollution and coastal development, which are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs. Given this information, it meets Vulnerable under D2 and the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2. The invasive lionfish may constitute a further threat to its population, however, further research is needed. It has been documented in the diet, but cleaner gobies are generally not considered preferred lionfish prey items. Therefore, in the Gulf of Mexico it is listed as EN B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii). This species should be monitored as further loss of coral could quickly cause it to regionally qualify for CR.
habitat: Elacatinus prochilos is a reef-associated cleaner goby that occurs in groups near coral heads with a preference for Montastrea annularis and sponges (Lieske and Myers 1994, Wilson 1998, Dennis et al. 2004). At coral cleaning stations it is more frequently solitary or found in small groups, while groups of up to 40 individuals were observed on sponge cleaning stations. It forms dominance hierarchies based on body size. Differences in substrate are linked to marked differences in social behaviour, cleaning activity and diet, with gobies on sponges cleaning less than gobies on corals (Whiteman and Côté 2004). Fish that range in size from six to 34 mm can be found co-occurring on the same substrate (Wilson 2005). This species is monogamous (Whiteman and Côté 2004) and sexes can be distinguished by the shape of the urogenital papilla (Thresher 1984). It consumes Gnathiid isopod larvae and caligid copepods in addition to fish scales, mucous, coral polyps and sponges. It is thought to consume less ectoparasites than other Caribbean and Pacific members of the genus (Arnal and Côte 2000). It does not undergo ontogenetic habitat shifts except when reproductive individuals leave live coral heads and build nests in small holes within the reef; however, young fish and fish of reproductive size are often present on coral heads together (Wilson 2005, Wilson pers. comm. 2011).
threats: Elacatinus prochilos is likely impacted by loss of coral reef habitat. There was an overall 59% decline in coral cover in the entire Caribbean between 1970-2011, and specifically an average of approximately 20% within the range of this species (Jackson et al. 2014). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). This area is impacted by commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area and runoff contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants (Ortiz-Lozano 2012). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). It has been recorded in the diet of the invasive Lionfish in the Mexican Caribbean, however, this is likely not a major threat considering lionfish uncommonly consume cleaner fishes (Villasenor-Derbez and Herrera-Perez 2014, Green and Cote 2014).
population: Elacatinus prochilos is abundant. Populations have been described as unstructured (Whiteman and Côté 2004, Wilson 2005). Despite an extended pelagic larval duration of 21 days, the retention of larvae of a sister and co-occurring species (E. evelynae) is almost exclusively localized. This indicates that the potential for subpopulations to receive propagules from elsewhere is very low (Taylor and Hellberg 2003).
range: Elacatinus prochilos is distributed in the western Atlantic from Veracruz, Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico and in the Caribbean from Jamaica along the Antilles to Tobago and from Quintana Roo, Mexico to Roatan, Honduras and Las Isles de Cisne (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is known from three potentially widely separated subpopulations (Colin 2010). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 3,214 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1970-2011 (41 years), the following coral cover declines were directly observed within its range: 17% Veracruz (1965-1999), 18% USVI, 30% Puerto Rico, 6% Barbados, 28% Jamaica, and 16.5% Belize (average 20%). Furthermore, considering it specifically prefers the boulder star coral, Montastrea annularis, its AOO is therefore assumed to be less than 2,000 km2. The subpopulation in the Gulf of Mexico is restricted to the Veracruz Reef System, where its AOO is 25 km2 and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,915 km2. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014).
useTrade: Elacatinus prochilos has been used as an indicator of habitat quality (Wilson 2005). It could possibly be targeted for the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Although the species may be assessed as Endangered because of restricted distribution and threats to the habitat, the species was just recently described (2010) and is assessed as Data Deficient pending further surveys from other parts of the Kaladan drainage in order to confirm its restricted range.
habitat: The species has been recorded from clear freshwater streams with sandy and rocky beds.
threats: Deforestation and siltation may cause habitat loss of the species since it has the habit of clinging to hard substrata with the help of its adhesive device. The proposed Kaladan multi-purpose project which involves waterway transport from Sittwe port in Myanmar to Mizoram (India) in future may also disturb the habitat of the fish. There are proposals for dam construction across Kaladan river.
population: No information available.
range: The species is known only from the type locality on the Kaladan (Chimtuipui) River, Mizoram, India.
useTrade: The fish does not have value in trade. However it may be used for local consumption. It may also have ornamental value because of its peculiar shape, but at present no information is available.
conservationActions: Further information on the population, distribution, and impact of current and future threats is required for this recently described species.

rationale: Atractosteus spatula has a large distribution from central and southeastern United States to eastern Mexico, Nicaragua and northwestern Costa Rica. The species is uncommon to rare in most of its range but abundant enough to support fisheries in some areas.
