Batagur baska has been exploited long-term for local subsistence and ritualistic consumption as well as some regional trade, including supply to the Calcutta markets in the 19th and 20th centuries. Harvest of its eggs has been extensive as the eggs are highly prized for consumption and can be collected at known sites at predictable times.

The species’ use of estuarine and mangrove habitats and sandy nesting beaches means it has been significantly impacted by habitat loss, as estuaries are prime locations for human settlement and industrial development, mangrove areas are cleared for fuelwood and for shrimp and other aquaculture development, and sandy banks and beaches are exploited for sand as building material and tourist developments.

The extent of threat posed by entanglement in fishing nets, the effects of altered water flow from hydrological mega-projects (dams, reservoirs, river diversion) on nesting sites and habitat in general, or habitat pollution, have not been documented as specific threats, but have likely impacted the species.

Seizure records from illegal trade have reported both B. affinis and B. baska as ‘Batagur baska’; at least 139 live specimens of one of these two species were reported as seized from 6 illegal trade shipments during the period 2000-2015 (CITES CoP17 Doc73).
population:
In the 1980s a moderate to large breeding population of Batagur baska was thought to exist in the Sunderbans of Bangladesh (Moll 1985). It was considered uncommon and Critically Endangered by 2000 (Rashid and Khan 2000). There are no records of adults in recent years, with only some hatchlings caught (P. Praschag pers. comm 2018). There are 8 females and about 26 males, with 230 juveniles in captivity (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).

Populations of Batagur baska in the Sunderbans in India were considered abundant in the 19th Century, but had declined to very small populations by the 1970s (Moll 1985) and to an estimated 10 breeding females by 1995 (Choudhury et al. 2000). The total Indian population was estimated as fewer than 40 animals, with about three nests produced per year, although there was hope that more animals and/or nesting sites might exist and be found with intensive survey efforts (Lucknow Red List Workshop participants, 2005). Participants at the 2011 Singapore Red List Workshop estimated that about 30 adult animals remained. In India, there are 8 males and 7 females; and 300 juveniles in captivity (S. Singh pers. comm. 2018).

Myanmar: Historically Batagur baska was numerous in the Ayeyarwady delta in Myanmar (Maxwell 1911), but populations had declined to a few nesting animals in the early 1980s (Moll 1985) and there are apparently no records from the wild in recent years, despite surveys. Currently, only three females remain in two pagoda ponds (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).

In Austria, there are two males, three females and 15 juveniles held in an assurance colony (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).
range: Batagur baska once ranged from Orissa and West Bengal in India through Bangladesh and Myanmar (lower Ayayarwady, Sittaung and Thanlwin [Salween]), and possibly as far south as the Andaman Sea side of Thailand at the Kra river. It is now limited to the Sundabans area of India and Bangladesh, with three females in two different temple ponds in Myanmar (S. Singh and P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018). Populations of river terrapins in Southeast Asia previously referred to this species are now considered a separate closely related species, the Southern River Terrapin (Batagur affinis).
useTrade: Batagur baska has been heavily exploited for its flesh and eggs, typically for local subsistence and ritualistic consumption.
conservationActions:
Batagur baska has been included in CITES Appendix I since 1975, prohibiting all forms of international commercial trade. It is also protected under Schedule I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), which includes endangered species that may only be hunted under exceptional circumstances, under licence from both federal and provincial authorities. Myanmar formerly had laws controlling egg collection, but with near extirpation of the terrapin within the country, such laws are now antiquated (Moll 2009). Marine and freshwater turtles are included in the Myanmar Fishery Law, and Myanmar Protection of Wildlife, Wild Plants and Conservation of Natural Areas Law of 1994, however, wildlife laws in Myanmar are poorly enforced. Batagur baska is not listed under the Bangladesh Wildlife Preservation (Amendment) Act (BWPA) 1974.

Batagur baska has been recorded from Sunderban Tiger Reserve (W Bengal) and Bhitarkanika Wild Life Sanctuary (Orissa) in India (Hanfee 1999), and is apparently now extinct at the latter site (Lucknow Red List Workshop participants 2005).

The species has historically received some captive management efforts in India. The Sundarbans subpopulation receives significant unofficial protection from the tiger and dense mosquito populations inhabiting the Sundarbans, but with tiger poaching at an all-time high, this effect may have disappeared.

Ensuring the survival of Batagur baska in the wild will require strict implementation of existing protective measures for the last remaining populations, vigilant protection of remaining habitat for these populations, and further coordinated population management and restoration efforts, including captive breeding and headstarting. Working with local communities to reduce and eventually eliminate egg poaching appears essential. The opportunities for a major Bangladesh-India transboundary conservation project for the Sundarbans, targeted for funding by the UNDP, warrant investigation.

Moll et al. (2009) suggested that unless some previously unknown viable population is discovered, captive breeding programs may be necessary for remaining wild individuals until such time that it is feasible to reestablish a wild population within sanctuaries (Moll et al. 2009).

rationale: Alosa alabamae is a coastal, schooling, and anadromous species that returns to natal rivers to spawn. Historically, this species was very widely distributed throughout the coastal waters and associated rivers of the Gulf of Mexico. However, very little is known about this species within its marine range. As this is an anadromous species, it has been heavily impacted by habitat alteration and dam placement that prohibits it from reaching natal spawning grounds throughout its range. As a direct result, its global population has undergone declines in abundance compared to historical levels. Additionally, there are estimated declines in Area of Occupancy (AOO) approaching 30% over the most recent ten years available (2001 – 2010), thought to conservatively represent three generation lengths. More recent distribution information or population abundance estimates (2011 – 2020) are not available. Based on limited reports of successful threat mitigation throughout its range, it is inferred that the rate of decline in AOO has not changed. It is therefore suspected that the declines in the global population size have tracked closely with declines in AOO and are nearing 30%. This species’ relatively short generation length coupled with relatively recent Population Viability Analyses and recent reports of attempts to increase available spawning habitat (e.g., ‘conservation locking’, fish passages, etc.) in parts of its range indicates recovery from low population levels over time in the absence of threats may be possible. However, despite local information on conservation efforts and success using these mitigative techniques in parts of its range, no current evidence is available to suggest these initiatives are taking place on a wide enough scale to cause a drastic increase in spawning habitat availability at this time, despite urgency expressed by state managers and researchers dating back to at least the late 1990s. Alosa alabamae nearly meets the requirements for Vulnerable under criterion A2ac; therefore, it is conservatively assessed as Near Threatened. Additional conservation actions should be taken to mitigate current spawning restrictions and provide further access to suitable spawning habitats. Further research is urgently needed regarding this species' population abundance as it may in fact, qualify for a threatened category.
habitat:
This is an anadromous species that presumably spends much of its life schooling in coastal marine waters before migrating into natal rivers to spawn (Mickle et al. 2015). It is known to a maximum standard length of 51 cm (Whitehead 1985). Little is known about its ecology when utilizing marine habitats (Mickle et al. 2015), but it is thought that it primarily feeds in coastal marine waters (Mettee and O'Neil 2003) before migrating up into rivers during spring months (February – May: Mickle et al. 2015). Kern et al. (2017) reports that upstream movement in the Lower Flint River, Georgia is greatest during April – mid-May. Juveniles reside in their natal drainage during the summer and fall and migrate to the Gulf of Mexico in late fall or winter (Barkuloo et al. 1993). Overall, the spawning habitat requirements of this species varies. Researchers support that this species spawns in shoal habitat downstream of the JWLD based on observations of the species congregating over the shoals during spawning season, as well as usage by other spawning anadromous species, such as the Gulf Sturgeon, Acipenser oxyrinchus desotoi (NOAA 2017). In northwest Florida, spawning occurs in moderate currents over coarse sand and gravel (Laurence and Yerger 1966, Mills 1972). Adults selected limerock boulder substrate and used sandy substrate in the same proportion of its availability as preferred spawning grounds in the Lower Flint River, Georgia (Kern et al. 2017). Mettee et al. (1996) suspects that spawning occurs in late afternoon or at night. In Missouri, young have been captured in swift water about rock wing dikes in the Osage River and over rocky shoals with a noticeable current in the Gasconade River (Mettee and O’Neil 2003).

Males reach sexual maturity between 1 to 5 years of age and females at 2 to 6 years in the Choctawhatchee River, Alabama and Florida (Mettee and O’Neil 2003). Age-2 and -3 adults are the most prevalent age class of spawning adults and repeat spawning is common, but the percentage of returning spawners is highly variable among years (Laurence and Yerger 1966, Mettee and O’Neil 2003). Given that it is known to have a maximum longevity of up to 6 years and females are known to reach maturity as early as two years (Mettee and O'Neil 2003), declines in population abundance and/or distribution should therefore be estimated over a time period of 10 years (thought to conservatively represent three generation lengths for this species).
threats: As this is an anadromous fish that requires an extensive spawning migration from coastal marine waters into natal rivers, the decline of this species’ global population and distribution is likely to be due to the modification and impoundment of riverine systems (Smith et al. 2011, NOAA 2017). Locks and dams built for navigation, hydroelectric generation, and flood control have effectively blocked migration routes to many historic upstream spawning areas for this species (Robison and Buchanan 1988, Mirarchi et al. 2004). High-lift navigation dams on the Alabama and Tombigbee rivers have blocked spawning migrations in the Mobile basin. Furthermore, streams have been degraded by siltation and pollution, and commercial and navigational dredging of sand bars has further degraded or eliminated some spawning habitats. Suspected threats to the remaining subpopulations in Alabama include increased sedimentation, pesticide runoff from agricultural operations, prolonged drought, and possible reservoir construction for water supply on major tributaries (Mettee in Mirarchi et al. 2004). Additionally, NOAA (2017) suggests that low population abundance also poses a moderate threat to this species. This species is suspected to have been negatively impacted by threats within its marine distribution (Gulf of Mexico), possibly from impacts stemming from the Deepwater Horizon Oil spill, given the poor physiological condition and visible wounds/lesions present on the body of captured adults during spawning runs in the years following the oil spill and anecdotal evidence of other fish species with similar lesions; however, this cause is unconfirmed and the physiological condition improved in 2014 (Sammons 2014). In the past, harvesting in the Ohio River was considered a major threat to this species; however, no commercial harvest records exist after the early 1900s (Hildenbrand 1963), and is no longer considered a threat. More research is urgently needed to determine the current (2011 – 2020) extent of suspected decline in abundance and estimated decline in available spawning habitat from these threats.
population:
OVERALL POPULATION INFORMATION

Limited population information is available for this species throughout its range and the total global adult population size is unknown; however, declines at least approaching 30% are suspected. Most of the species-specific information available is from the Apalachicola River in northwest Florida (NOAA 2017). The studies conducted in the ACF (Apalachicola, Chattahoochee, Flint) river system are the only abundance estimates, either historic or current, for this species in any river system (NOAA 2017). General information presented below refer to the historic or current distribution of this species in river systems and are primarily based on capture data from multi-species surveys, project monitoring, incidental catches and anecdotal information (NOAA 2017). It is also known to migrate into the marine waters along the Gulf coast; however, little is known about this species within the marine environment, despite it spending a majority of its life there (NOAA 2017).

Overall, this species has declined, and in some cases, has been extirpated from large portions of its historical range (Smith et al. 2011). For example, it is suspected to have severely declined or may be extirpated from Iowa, Tennessee and Louisiana (Mettee and O’Neil 2003). It has been eliminated from much of its former inland distribution, especially in the Mobile Basin and the Mississippi River Valley (M. Warren 1999 pers. comm., Boschung and Mayden 2004); subpopulations are small and are now very rare throughout the entire Mississippi River basin (Lee et al. 1980, Robison and Buchanan 1988, Etnier and Starnes 1993, Pflieger 1997). It is considered rare or extirpated in much of its former range in Alabama (Boschung and Mayden 2004), including the upper Tombigbee, Cahaba, Coosa, and upper Alabama rivers (Mettee in Mirarchi et al. 2004). As of around 1990, abundance was evidently still declining in the Pearl River system of Louisiana and Mississippi (Gunning and Suttkus 1990), and Ross (2001) reported that this species may be extirpated in the Pearl River.

Schaffler et al. (2015) reports that the Apalachicola River system has the largest extant subpopulation, but remnant subpopulations do occur in the Choctawhatchee River in Florida and Alabama, and the Pascagoula River in Mississippi. NOAA (2017) indicates this species was previously distributed within roughly 21 major river systems and associated tributaries at least throughout some time in history. It is estimated that ten out of the 21 known river systems still support spawning subpopulations (<50%) with suitable, accessible habitat, and include the Apalachicola drainage, parts of the Mississippi, Missouri, Meramec, White, Ouachita, Pascagoula, Escambia (and Conecuh), Choctawhatchee and Suwannee rivers (NOAA 2017). It is suspected that this species' global population abundance has greatly diminished over the past 20 – 50 years range and is likely, or potentially extirpated from much of its former inland distribution where it has not been observed in many years, including the Ohio, Arkansas, Red, Illinois and Mary rivers, as well as the upper and lower Mississippi River mainstem (NOAA 2017). It is also considered rare or is sporadically recorded in parts of its range, such as in the Mobile Bay and Mobile River basin, Lake Pantchartrain, Lake Maurepas, and the Tangipahoa, Pearl, Ochlockonee and the Econfina rivers (NOAA 2017).

As global population data are not available, the decline in population size was suspected based on the decline in AOO. Based on its distribution between 2001-2010, and the inference that the rate of decline has remained constant, it is suspected that the total global population size has declined by nearly 30%. Current distribution data as well as abundance data are urgently needed.

RIVER/BASIN SPECIFIC INFORMATION:

Apalachicola River Drainage:

Most of the information regarding this species is from the Apalachicola River in northwest Florida where the largest subpopulation remains below the Jim Woodruff Lock and Dam (JWLD). The ACF River system contains the largest spawning subpopulation of this species within its range, although the subpopulation may be several orders of magnitude smaller than historical levels (Sammons 2014, Schaffler et al. 2015, NOAA 2017).

Previously, researchers collected 141 Alabama shad in the Apalachicola in 1966 over the course of 17 sampling days using a variety of methods (Laurence and Yerger 1966), 251 were captured in 1969–1970 (Mills 1972) and 400 were captured from 1994 to 2000 in the Choctawhatchee River (Mettee and O’Neil 2003). These relatively low catch rates suggest low abundances in previous years (Ely et al. 2008).

Apalachicola Alabama Shad exhibit low genetic diversity, which may inhibit its ability to respond to unanticipated environmental and anthropogenic changes (Moyer 2012). Smith et al. (2011) conducted a population viability analysis (PVA) of Alabama Shad in the Apalachicola River System and predicted that the subpopulation was increasing and could reach carrying capacity in about 40 years given the conditions remain favourable (e.g., allowing passage of spawning adults through the dam). However, this subpopulation declined rapidly after 2013 from unknown causes and has remained at a low level (S. Sammons pers. comm. April 2020).

Despite apparent declines in global population size over time, the subpopulation of this species within the ACF River system has remained self-sustaining and therefore, a project to restore passage to upstream spawning habitats has been initiated (Schaffler et al. 2015). Cooperative studies supported by many local, academic, state, and federal partners have started tracking the movements of this species in 2005 in the Apalachicola River (USFWS 2008, Ely et al. 2008, TNC 2010, NOAA 2017). Results of this collaborative study showed that the existing lock at JWLD could be operated to allow movement upriver and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers began ‘conservation locking’ to provide this species with upstream access (NOAA 2017). Abundance of this species prior to 2005, including prior to the installation of the dam, were never estimated (Ely et al. 2008), but these improvements in facilitating fish passage is thought to have allowed recruitment to increase in recent years (Young et al. 2012, Schaffler et al. 2015) and are expected to be a major component of the future restoration of this species in the Apalachicola River (Kern and Sammons 2015).

Adult subpopulation estimates (spring), adult CPUE (spring) and juvenile CPUE (fall) are available for this species in the ACF River system between 2005 – 2016 and are based on mark-recapture methods (NOAA 2017). Adult subpopulation estimates show high variability (approximately 122,500 individuals estimated in 2012, compared to 300 and 0 individuals estimated in 2015 and 2016, respectively) during this time series but are based on whether ‘conservation locking’ took place (NOAA 2017). During periods of ‘conservation locking’ this species was successfully able to pass upstream and yield higher subpopulation estimates overall indicating better recruitment (Schaffler et al. 2015, NOAA 2017). However, in the years where ‘conservation locking’ did not take place due to lock maintenance and upgrades (2013 and 2014) and in the years directly after (2015 and 2016), adult subpopulation estimates were low (i.e., below 2,000 individuals). Spawning subpopulation size estimates were attempted in the Apalachicola River in 2014; however, too few individuals were collected to allow for a subpopulation estimate (Sammons 2014). More recently, egg collection for this species was more successful than larvae collection, but still much lower than that of the similar American Shad (Alosa sapidissima) and it is possible that the low efficiency resulted from low densities of adults, as few adult individuals were collected below JWLD in 2017 (Sammons 2018).

Spawning individuals are now able to access over 150 miles (241.4 km) of necessary historical habitat and spawning areas in the ACF River system for the first time in over 50 years now that the JWLD lock operates within their natural spawning cues (TNC 2010, NOAA 2017). ‘Conservation locking’ is thought to be making a tremendous impact on this species within the ACF River system; adults are most commonly found in the Flint River arm of Lake Seminole above the JWLD (Sammons 2013, Sammons 2014) and juveniles are likely able to move downstream to contribute to the adult stock (NOAA 2017). Despite the enhancement of spawning and recruitment of this species due to ‘conservation locking’ (Young 2010, 2011, Sammons and Young 2012, Schaffler et al. 2015, NOAA 2017), and although the ACF River system has had the largest known subpopulation of this species for decades, the lack of ‘conservation locking’ in 2013 and 2014 due to maintenance, combined with environmental conditions (cold and flooding) and poor condition of spawning adults (unexplained visible wounds) probably produced the weakest year class since research began on this species in 2005 (Sammons 2014, NOAA 2017).

Temperature is one of the main cues for this species to enter the ACF River system to spawn (Kern et al. 2017). The unusually low water temperatures in 2013 and 2014 may have hindered the usual spawning cues for this species resulting in a limited number of fish migrating upstream (Sammons 2014). High water and discharge during this time may have also hindered catch rates, but more likely spawning subpopulation size was very low (Sammons 2014).

Differences in the trends of the adult subpopulation of this species can be partially explained by differing sampling effort due to environmental conditions and funding levels; however, researchers suspect the spawning subpopulation in the ACF River system in 2013 – 2016 was dangerously low compared to the 2009 – 2012 spawning subpopulations (Sammons 2014, NOAA 2017). Access to the more than 150 miles of spawning habitat for this species above Lake Seminole through ‘conservation locking’ appears to be necessary to increase the current low population levels.

Similar to other Clupeids, this species exhibits natural variability, and given that there are no historic estimates to compare to recent populations trends, it is very difficult to interpret population trends for this species (NOAA 2017). The studies conducted in the ACF River system are the only abundance estimates for this species throughout its global range, either historical or current, for this species in any river system (NOAA 2017).

Mississippi River:

This species was historically found in several parts of the Mississippi River and its tributaries (NOAA 2017). For example, it was known as far north as Keokuk, Iowa (Coker 1930), the Ohio River at Louisville (Evermann 1902) and eastern Oklahoma (Moore 1957, Miller and Robison 2004). Despite sporadic observations of this species and reports of depletion in the basin (e.g., Lee et al. 1980, Page and Burr 1991), several small spawning subpopulations remain (NOAA 2017).

Upper Mississippi River Mainstem:

The Upper Mississippi River is the portion upstream of Cairo, Illinois. This species was recorded in a 1994 annual status report as being captured in a long-term resource monitoring program (Grutreuter et al. 1997); however, no species data (i.e., number caught, gear used, location, etc.) were reported. Currently, there are 10 locks or dams on the Upper Mississippi River that border the state of Iowa and an addition seven locks and dams south of Iowa which likely prevent this species from reaching historical spawning grounds (Steuck et al. 2010). Iowa DNR has not collected this species in the Upper Mississippi River in more than 25 years (Smith et al. 2011), and no recent information is available to suggest otherwise between the year 2011 and present day (2020).

Missouri River:

The Missouri Fish and Wildlife Information System maintained by the Missouri Department of Conservation (MDC) states that this species spawns in the Missouri River and two of its tributaries, the Gasconade and Osage Rivers (MDC 2015). Galat (2005) reported the presence of this species in the lower Missouri River in 2005 and stated that it is rare in the Ozark Plateaus region in southern Missouri. The MDC reported this species has been captured in the Missouri River at least up until 2012 in multi-species surveys (NOAA 2017).

Meramec River:

Burr et al. (2004) and Buchannan et al. (2012) list the Meramec River as one of the remaining spawning rivers of this species in Missouri and is supported by the Missouri Department of Conservation (MDC 2015).

Lower Mississippi Mainstem:

The Lower Mississippi River (south of Cairo, Illinois) used to provide a means for this species to reach many of its tributaries; however, no individuals have been found in the lower portion of the waterway in recent years in annual fish surveys conducted by USGS (Smith et al. 2011, NOAA 2017). 

Ohio River:

This species used to be present and abundant enough to support a small commercial fishery in the Ohio River during the late 19th century; however, by 1989, this species was extirpated from this river (Pearson and Pearson 1989). It has not been collected or observed from this river or the Tennessee River since the early 1990s (Smith et al. 2011).

Arkansas River:

No records of this species exist from the Arkansas River since the 1890s; however, few individuals may have been captured from its tributaries in the 1950s, but this is unclear (Lindsey et al. 1983). This species may have been extirpated from the watershed due to dams (NOAA 2017). In a two-year intensive field sampling study of this species in Arkansas rivers, special emphasis was placed on sampling in the Ouachita and Arkansas rivers in 2019; however, conditions were not suitable for safe and effective fish sampling due to excessive flooding, therefore sampling did not take place in the Arkansas River (Eggleton et al. 2019). In 2020, sampling was conducted in the Arkansas River below the four most downstream dams, but no individuals were collected (Eggleton pers comm. June 2020). However, sampling was delayed due to field restrictions from the COVID-19 outbreak and did not allow for sampling to take place during optimal spawning times (Eggleton pers. comm. June 2020).

Red River:

This species has not been collected from the Red River or its tributaries since around the 1980s (e.g., Matthews and Robison 1988, Buchannan et al. 2003, Smith et al. 2011).

Illinois and Marys Rivers:

There are historical records of this species within the Illinois rivers (Smith et al. 2011); however, the abundance is not known (NOAA 2017). This species appears to have been extirpated from many Illinois rivers and are considered rare in the state (NOAA 2017). Annual field studies have yielded no additional records of this species (Smith et al. 2011).

White River:

The White River (Arkansas) is a minor tributary of the Mississippi River. Three juveniles were collected from the White River in 2006, which confirms there is probably a small spawning subpopulation (Buchanan et al. 2012). In an ongoing two-year sampling study of this species in Arkansas rivers (2019 – 2020: Eggleton et al. 2019), three reaches of the White River were sampled for this species in 2020 and resulted in zero collected individuals (Eggleton pers. comm. June 2020). However, sampling was delayed due to field restrictions from the COVID-19 outbreak and did not allow for sampling to take place during optimal spawning times (Eggleton pers. comm. June 2020).

Ouachita River:

The Ouachita River is a minor tributary of the Mississippi River and includes the Little Missouri and Saline Rivers. This species is rare in Arkansas rivers overall and only a handful of adults have ever been collected; however, most individuals (adult and juvenile) have been taken from the middle Ouachita River and its largest tributary, the Little Missouri River (Eggleton et al. 2019). The Ouachita and Little Missouri Rivers are thought to contain very small spawning subpopulations of this species given that a majority of the 767 individuals ever collected (since 1879) were juveniles, and may represent the limit of their inland spawning migrations (Eggleton et al. 2019). There have been no recent reports of this species in the Saline River (Buchanan et al. 1999); only a single specimen was collected in 1972 (Eggleton et al. 2019). An ongoing, two-year sampling study (2019 – 2020) of this species in the Ouachita River basin represents one of the most intensive efforts ever made to collect this species in Arkansas, but has yielded only a single adult male specimen and zero juveniles (Eggleton et al. 2019). Although it is likely this species was present in the Ouachita basin in 2019, severe hydrological conditions (e.g., excessive flooding) during the likely spawning window limited the ability for researchers to collect data on this species (Eggleton et al. 2019).

Lake Pantchartrain, Lake Maurepas, and the Tangipahoa River:

This species is caught sporadically within Louisiana, but data are limited within its rivers (Smith et al. 2011).

Pearl River:

This species has been reported in low numbers from the Pearl River in multi-species studies; however, this may be due to limited sampling effort during spawning periods (NOAA 2017). Smith et al. (2011) reported no individuals have been captured since the 1990s and Ross (2001) reported that this species may be extirpated in the Pearl River, but museum records attained by Tulane University in 2004 suggests otherwise (FishNet2 portal accessed March 2020).

Pascagoula River:

This Pascagoula River system (Pascagoula, Leaf and Chickasawhay Rivers) is the only system within the state of Mississippi inhabited by this species (Mickle et al. 2010, Mickle 2010, NOAA 2017) and has one of the remaining spawning subpopulations of this species (Mickle 2006).

Mobile Bay and the Mobile River Basin:

This species was historically prevalent in the Mobile River basin (Evermann and Kendall 1897) and some studies suggest that subpopulations persist (e.g., Boschung and Mayden 2004, Mettee in Mirarchi et al. 2004); however, few individuals have been captured throughout the basin in recent years (NOAA 2017). For example, the most recent Mobile Basin records are limited to single adult individuals collected in the Black Warrior River in 1998 (the first record from that river in more than 100 years) and in the Alabama River in 1993 and 1995 (Mettee et al. 1996). In an effort to establish an annual spawning run in the Alabama River, 53 individuals in 2014 and 27 individuals in 2015 were captured below the JWLD in the Apalachicola River (Kern and Sammons 2015). Collected individuals were tagged with transmitters and stocked below the Claiborne Lock and Dam in 2014 and below the Miller’s Ferry Lock and Dam in 2015 in the Alabama River (Kern and Sammons 2015). No Alabama Shad were found to have successfully navigated upstream of either dam (Kern and Sammons 2015).

Escambia River and Conecuh River:

This species was historically documented in the Escambia and Conecuh Rivers as early as 1900 (Evermann and Kendall 1900) and contains one of the known remaining spawning subpopulations (Robison and Buchanan 1988, Mettee et al. 1996, Smith et al. 2011).

Choctawhatchee River:

Some studies indicate there are small spawning subpopulations of this species in southern Alabama including the Choctawhatchee and Pea Rivers (Robison and Buchanan 1988, Barkuloo et al. 1993, Mettee et al. 1996, Adams et al. 2000, Mettee and O’Neil 2003, Young 2010).

Ochlockonee River:

This species was historically present in the Ochlockonee River between Georgia and Florida (NOAA 2017). Few specimens have been taken from this river since the late 1970s (NOAA 2017).

Econfina River:

Historical data for this species are not available from the Ecofina River, but a single individual was captured here in 2006 (NOAA 2017).

Suwannee River:

Historically, the Suwannee River has been the easternmost boundary of this species’ range (Herald and Strickland 1946) and Smith et al. (2011) reports that there is still a spawning subpopulation in the river. However, more recent information is unavailable.
range:
This species was historically widely distributed throughout coastal waters and river systems along the Gulf of Mexico off the United States and eastern Oklahoma in the Ouachita River system, east to the Mississippi River and the Suwannee River in Florida (Coker 1930, Lee et al. 1980, Pattillo et al. 1997, Kern et al. 2017, NOAA 2017). It was known to reach freshwater rivers as far inland as Oklahoma, Iowa and West Virginia (Smith et al. 2011). According to Mickle et al. (2010), the range of this species has contracted to only the Pascagoula River drainage in Mississippi; however, Young et al. (2012) documents the existence of a reproducing population in the Apalachicola River in Florida and Smith et al. (2011) reported the present distribution extends up the Mississippi River drainage into eastern Arkansas and central Missouri.

NOAA (2013, 2017) recognizes the current freshwater range of this species to include the Apalachicola, Chattahoochee, Flint (ACF) River system above Jim Woodruff Lock and Dam (JWLD) in Florida/Georgia/Alabama, the Pea and Choctawhatchee rivers in Alabama, the Pearl River in Louisiana/Mississippi, and the Little Missouri River in Arkansas as reported by Smith et al. (2011). Limited information is available about its distribution in marine waters. The depth range of this species is unknown; however, similar to other closely related species, it probably occupies depths between 0–50 metres.

As spawning occurs in riverine environments, its freshwater extent was used to determine the area of occupancy (AOO), calculated from a 4 km² grid, and extent of occurrence (EOO), based on a minimum convex polygon. Based on the rivers where this species was distributed in 2001 and 2010 (Smith et al. 2011), the AOO declined by from 8,816 km² in 2001 to 6,576 km² in 2010 and the EOO declined by from 897,311 km² in 2001 and 341,562 km² in 2010. Although more recent distribution data are not available, the rate of decline in AOO was inferred to have remained constant over the last 10 years. Therefore, we extrapolated the data to the present using an exponential regression, which results in an inferred decline in AOO of 27.8%.
useTrade: Alabama Shad were harvested for food from the Ohio River in Indiana and Kentucky, several rivers in Alabama, and the Ouachita River in Arkansas in the 1800s (Mettee and O'Neil 2003). Formerly, commercial fishing in the Ohio River amounted to several thousand pounds harvested per year and was considered a major threat to this species. Commercial landings of this species were reported at 3,165 kg in 1889 and 48 kg in 1902 (Hildenbrand 1963). It disappeared from fishery statistics in the early 1900s and commercial landings have not been reported since (Hildenbrand 1963), possibly due to the construction of high lift locks and dams that blocked upstream migrations (Mettee and O'Neil 2003).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Species of Concern List (Smith et al. 2011) and has been petitioned to be included as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act (ESA: NOAA 2017). Despite being listed as a Species of Concern, this status does not carry any procedural or substantive federal protections (NOAA 2017). An overall paucity of available data regarding the life history and abundance of this species has ultimately prevented it from receiving more urgent conservation efforts based on the criteria used for the ESA (Grice et al. 2014, NOAA 2017). Regardless of the lack of federal protection, it is protected by some states where it is currently, or was previously distributed (Meadows et al. 2008, Mickle et al. 2015, NOAA 2017, Eggleton et al. 2019), as many have enacted recovery and conservation plans in response to river-wide declines.

State and Federal agencies are working with conservation groups and researchers to restore passage of Alabama Shad to their historic range upstream of Jim Woodruff Lock and Dam (JWLD) in the Apalachicola basin. In 2008, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers began ‘conservation locking’ by operating the lock at JWLD to provide Alabama shad access to upstream habitat (NOAA 2013). Subpopulation increases have been documented upon the strategic opening of a navigation lock on the Jim Woodruff dam by maximizing attraction flow near the lock entrance and increasing the time the upper gates are open during an afternoon locking cycle to allow fish to pass to spawning grounds (Young et al. 2012).  Efforts to pass shad through the lock have resulted in the passage of shad through Lake Seminole and into the Chattahoochee and Flint River systems in Georgia. These efforts are expected to continue to be a major component supporting the restoration of this species in the ACF River system (Kern and Sammons 2015).

The translocation of adults and supplemental stocking of juvenile fish from the ACF river system has been attempted in the past in Georgia with some success (T. Ingram pers comm. June 2020); however, adults transported into the Alabama River showed with little success due to a low number of individuals at the JWLD lock (Kern and Sammons 2015). Approximately 10,000 fry in 2013 and 102,000 fry in 2017 were stocked in the upper Flint River above Lake Blackshear that were spawned from adults captured below the JWLD; however, stock contribution was never evaluated (T. Ingram pers comm. June 2020). In 2012, roughly 100 adults captured below the JWLD were transported into to Lake Blackshear; young of the year were captured in fall gillnetting samples, thus indicating successful spawning of stocked adults (T. Ingram pers comm. June 2020). In Alabama, adult individuals were captured below the JWLD in 2014 and 2015 and transported into the Alabama River to establish and annual spawning run; however, no Alabama shad were found to have successfully navigated upstream of either dam (Kern and Sammons 2015). If numbers of this species increase in the future at the JWLD, it is likely that this method will be attempted again in Georgia and Alabama, as it may be one of the only ways to reintroduce this species into the mobile drainage (Kern and Sammons 2015, S. Sammons pers. comm. May 2020).

In an effort to establish an annual spawning run in the Alabama River, 53 individuals in 2014 and 27 individuals in 2015 were captured below the JWLD in the Apalachicola River (Kern and Sammons 2015). Collected individuals were tagged with transmitters and stocked below the Claiborne Lock and Dam in 2014 and below the Miller’s Ferry Lock and Dam in 2015 in the Alabama River (Kern and Sammons 2015). No Alabama Shad were found to have successfully navigated upstream of either dam (Kern and Sammons 2015).

Research into effective fish passages, restoration of hydrologic regimes, migrations, feeding, bycatch, spawning, rearing, and other habitat needs should be carried out (Meadows et al. 2008). Spawning habitats require protection and/or restoration, including maintaining flow regimes that would allow for large sandbars and preserve accumulation of large woody debris along steep riverbanks and enabling effective passage for fish throughout watershed drainages (Mickle et al. 2010, Buchanan et al. 2012). The variation in year-class strength typical to this genus suggests that subpopulations of Alabama shad can recover quickly to historic levels under favorable conditions (Ely et al. 2008). The majority of the subpopulation in the Apalachicola River system is dependent upon access to spawning in the Flint River; therefore, priorities to maintain the connectivity of this waterway are essential (Schaffler et al. 2015). Additionally, efforts to provide passage at other upstream barriers should be examined for the expansion of restoration efforts of this species (Sammons 2014), similar to efforts initiated at the JWLD.

Subpopulations could increase if favorable environmental conditions are restored throughout its current range and recovery may be high in parts of its range with unimpounded systems and where management actions have already allowed for upstream passage for spawning runs. Beyond this, there is a need for studies focused on the adult life stage in marine and estuarine environments (Sammons 2014, Mickle et al. 2015). Mettee and O'Neil (2003) recommend research on its distribution, spawning season variation, population size, fecundity, diet, and movements in the Mississippi River and its major tributaries and in Gulf Coast drainages containing known subpopulations. Future studies should also focus on potential environmental and biological mechanisms that may govern spawning stock size and survival (Sammons 2014).

rationale: The species has undergone a sharp decline in both stock and recruitment. The dramatic stock decline began in the late 19th century and continues to the present day. From the late 19th century to 1992 the population has experienced a decline of more than 80%. During the last ten to fifteen years a very large decrease in the abundance of this species has occurred. The average age of fishes is subsequently decreasing as a result of catch of adults by poachers for caviar. This has resulted in females reproducing only once in their lifetime. This species has therefore been assessed as Critically Endangered.
habitat:
Habitat: All types of benthic habitats in large rivers and lakes of the Amur River basin.

Biology: Semi-anadromous (anadromous fishes spend at least part of their life in salt water and return to rivers to breed). The Kaluga Sturgeon spawns in lower reaches of the Amur River in strong-current habitats in the main stream of the river on gravel or sandy-gravel bottom. Spawning peaks from the end of May to July. Adults spawn many times during their life cycle. Spawning periodicity is 4-5 years in females and 3-4 years in males. The generation length of the species is not less than 20 years (Krykhtin and Svirskii 1997, Berg 1948).
threats: The causes of the population decline are still overfishing, both legal and poaching (Vaisman and Fomenko 2007). Recently, environmental pollution in the Amur River basin threatens the habitat and reproduction of this species (Shmigirilov et al. 2007, Chen 2007).
population:
Currently, complete population data based on results of direct counts and fishery statistics do not exist for this species. A decline of catches has been observed since the end of the 19th century (Vaisman and Fomenko 2007). Towards the end of the 19th century, annual catch was approximately 500 tonnes. Before 1992 the annual catch was 92 tonnes. This indicates a greater than 80% decline in catches over 90 years (Vaisman and Fomenko 2007).

A hatchery is located in Luchegorsk at Khabarovsk district which contains a living collection of eight species of sturgeons (including the Kaluga Sturgeon) and hybrids. In 2007, this hatchery attempted the first re-stocking of juveniles of this this species into the Amur River.
range: The Kaluga Sturgeon inhabits the entire Amur River basin from the estuary to the river’s upper reaches. It occurs in tributaries - the Shilka, Onon, Argun, Nerch, Sungari, Nonni and Ussuri and Neijiang Rivers (Krykhtin and Svirskii 1997). It rarely occurs in Lake Khanka. Young specimens also appear in the coastal waters of the Sea of Okhotsk, near the northeastern part of the Tatar Strait, and in the Sea of Japan near the islands of Hokkaido and Honshu (Krykhtin and Svirskii 1997, Shmigirilov et al. 2007). There are two separate populations in the Amur River tributaries - Zeya River and Bureya River (Krykhtin and Svirskii 1997, Shmigirilov et al. 2007, Chen 2007).
useTrade: This species is removed from the wild for human consumption and research.
conservationActions: The majority of 'conservation' measures historically were directed to control local and national fisheries. Commercial sturgeon fishing was prohibited in the Soviet Union during the periods 1923-1930, 1958-1976 and from 1984 to the present (Vaisman and Fomenko 2007). The Kaluga Sturgeon was listed in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in 1998.

rationale: The species was historically known from the Caspian, Black, Azov and Adriatic Sea basins. It has been extirpated from the Adriatic (in the early 1970s, Gessner pers. comm.) and Azov Seas due to overfishing and loss of spawning sites due to dams. As the species is very long lived, individuals can still be caught in areas where their spawning sites have been cut off. The last wild population in the Black Sea basin migrates up the Danube river. All other Black Sea stocks are almost extirpated due to overfishing and impoundment of spawning rivers. In the Caspian basin, the last wild population migrates up the River Ural. The Volga population depends on stocking as the construction of Volgograd dam led to the loss of almost all of the species spawning sites in the river. Most of the few recorded females are in their first year of maturation. Based on catch data, and number of recorded spawning individuals it is estimated that the species has seen a wild native population decline of over 90% in the past three generations (a minimum of 60 years) and overfishing for meat and caviar will soon cause global extinction of the remaining natural wild populations. In the immediate future, survival can only depend on stocking and effective fisheries management and combating illegal fishing. Range states are also encouraged to provide protection to the species spawning and feeding grounds.
habitat:
At sea, this species is found in the pelagic zone, following food organisms. It migrates further upriver to spawn than any other sturgeon; however this migration has now been disrupted due to river regulation (in the Danube drainage up to Morava River). It spawns in strong-current habitats in the main course of large and deep rivers on stone or gravel bottom.

This species is anadromous (spending at least part of its life in salt water and returning to rivers to breed). Males reproduce for the first time at 10-15 years, females at 15-18 years, with an estimated generation length of 20-25 years. This species spawns every 3-4 years in April-June. A complicated pattern of spawning migrations includes one peak in late winter and spring and one in late summer and autumn. In spring, it migrates from the sea before spawning. Individuals migrating in autumn remain in the rivers until the following spring. Spawning occurs at temperature from 6 to 14 °C in the channel and spring flooded spawning grounds at a current speed of 0.8-1.2 m / sec. Spawners the late winter/spring run dominate the spawners in the Volga River (80%), whereas the late summer/autumn  run dominates in the Ural River. Yolk-sac larvae are pelagic for 7-8 days and drift with current. Juveniles migrate to sea during their first summer and remain there until maturity.

In the past this species was the largest fish of the Caspian Sea, reaching lengths of more than 5 m and a weight of 1,000 kg. The lifetime of such large specimens, apparently, exceeded 100 years. Currently there are individuals up to 280 cm, weighing up to 650 kg. Average length of females is 240, males is 220 cm, weight respectively is 130 and 65 kg. The maximum age of 53 years was observed in 2003.
 
Various environmental factors influence the distribution of the species in the Caspian Sea. One factor is water temperature, as mature Beluga prefer water temperatures not exceeding 30°C. They spend the spring and summer mostly in the northern and middle parts of the Caspian Sea and then move southwards to spend the winter in the southern areas, which coincides with highest densities of food organisms. The diet includes roach Rutilus rutilus (L.), common carp (Cyprinus carpio L.), herrings (Clupeidae), kilka (Clupeonella), crayfish (Astacus), gobies (Gobiidae), pike-perch (Sander lucioperca (L.)), birds, sturgeons (Acipenseridae), and even seal (Khodorevskaya et al., 1995). Mature individuals of Beluga are less sensitive to low temperature than the immature, as they feed in the northern part of the Caspian Sea under the ice. With water temperatures decreasing, Belugas reduce the range of depths at which they feed. Immature individuals in spring and autumn prefer the more desalinated sea areas. In summer the highest concentrations occur at the salinity of 3 to 7%. The largest concentrations of Beluga in the northern Caspian occur during the migration of its main prey organisms (herrings, kilka, gobies, roach, etc.).
threats:
Overfishing at sea and poaching in estuaries and rivers for meat and caviar is a major threat to the species. Overharvesting and a sharp increase in poaching has led to the largest and most mature specimens being removed from the population and reducing natural reproduction to almost zero (Krassikov and Fedin 1996). In the Ural river current fishing rates are 4 to 5 times sustainable levels (F Max) (Doukakis et al. accepted).

Bycatch is also a threat to the species. The species caviar is very high value (8,000 USD per kilo in 2009).

Impoundment of rivers has destroyed most of the species spawning grounds. The Volgograd dam, built in 1955, has decreased the area of available spawning grounds by 88-100% in the Volga river, similar areas have been reduced in the Terek and Sulak rivers from 132 ha and 202 ha, respectively. The Don river dam removed 68,000 ha of spawning ground and flow regulation in the Kuban river led to the loss of 140,000 ha (CITES 2000).

Due to the longevity of the species there is evidence of pesticide contamination, leading to many problems including reduced reproductive success (Gessner, J. pers comm.).

The Allee effect could also be a threat to the species.
population:
Global fisheries statistics show that there has been a 93% decline in catch from 1992 (520 tonnes) to 2007 (33 tonnes) (FAO 2009).

The number of Beluga annually entering the Volga dropped from 26,000 (1961-65) to 2,800 (1998-2002), a decline of 89% in 33 years (Khodorevskaya et al. 2009). Only 2,500 migrated up Ural in 2002 (Pikitch et al. 2005).

Currently it is thought that nearly 100% of Beluga in the Volga are hatchery reared, but there is evidence of spawning elsewhere in its distribution (Khodorevskaya et al. 2009). Despite intensive restocking in the Caspian Sea (91% of each generation is estimated to come from hatchery stock), the annual catch in the northern Caspian Sea has drastically fallen. Catches in the Caspian were: 1945-55 average of 1,380 tonnes; 1956-65 average of 1,283 tonnes; 1966-75 average of 1,623 tonnes; 1976-85 average of 849 tonnes; 1986-95 average of 506 tonnes; 1996-2003 (latest data) average of 60.8 tonnes (in Doukakis et al. accepted). This shows a decline of 95%. The official catch statistics support this trend, as they show that the species was abundant in 1938 and then stable to the late 1980s, with the major decline starting from 1990 to the present showing over a 90% decline in the past 60 years (see Khodorevskaya et al. 2009). The agreed Beluga catch quota for all of the Caspian Sea (2007/8 - 28th session of the Commission) was 99.8 tonnes; this quota was not achieved. The proportion of Beluga (to other sturgeon species) in trawl catches of the northern Caspian Sea in all seasons of observations was at an average of 11%. Over the recent years, this percentage has decreased to 8.3%, and the catch of beluga during trawl surveys did not exceed 31 specimens per year (Khodorevskaya et al. 2009).

Spawning numbers for the Volga from 1961-65 was 26,000, whilst in 1996/1997 it was 1,800 (Khodorevskaya et al. 2000), with 2,800 in 1998-2002 (Khodorevskaya et al. 2009).

In the Sea of Azov, between 1979-1981 it is estimated that 551,000 individuals existed (from stocked, and dominated by sub-adult and juveniles); in 1988-1993 there were 25,000 and after 1994 they were only caught sporadically, despite banning of commercial fishing of Beluga in 1986. After 1986 the major threat was from bycatch. Since 1994, 98% of individuals recorded in the Azov Sea have been juvenile. In 2001 the first individuals were produced from captive bred individuals and released (Chebanov and Koziritskaya 2007).

Catches in the Danube have also declined. In the mid-Danube the annual catch was 23 tonnes (average between 1972-76) which dropped to 7.5 tonnes (average between 1985-89), a decline of 67% in around 12 years (CITES 2000). In 2002, 21.3 tonnes were caught in Romania, whilst only 8.4 tonnes were caught in 2005, showing a 60% decline in three years. The percentage of catch quota achieved in Romania was 85% in 2002, 84% in 2003, 46% in 2004, and 34% in 2005. In 2006 the catching of Beluga was banned in the Danube (Paraschiv et al. 2006).
range: This species has been recorded in the basins of the Caspian, Black, Azov, and Adriatic Seas, however its current native wild distribution is restricted to the Black Sea (in the Danube only) and the Caspian Sea (in the Ural only). It is one of the largest anadromous fish in the Caspian Sea, where at least three Beluga populations have been identified by microsatellite technique (Pourkazemi 2008). It does occur in the Azov Sea, and Volga River but these are stocked fish.
useTrade: This species is targeted for its skin and as a leather. Caviar is also used as cosmetic and medicinal purposes. Intestine use as sauce (food) and to produce gelatine. Swim bladder used to produce glue.
conservationActions:
This species was listed on CITES Appendix II in 1998. Restocking programmes are ongoing. However the programmes do not compensate for the loss of natural reproduction and the populations continue to decline (CITES 2000).

The annual number of fingerlings released into the Volga show 0.4 million in 1951; 13.1 million between 1966-70 (average per year); 19.4 million between 1981-85; 11.3 million between 1996-2000; and 3 million between 2001-2005 (Khodorevskaya et al. 2009). The Report of the 28th Session of Caspian Bioresource Commission states that the total fingerling release of beluga in 2008 was 7.02 million from Russia, Iran and Khazakstan.

Some natural reproduction of the species remains in the Volga and Ural Rivers. However, at present the abundance of Beluga is extremely low. Since 2000 in Russia, it has only been caught for the purposes of reproduction (for hatcheries) and science. The protective measures at the feeding grounds are necessary to maintain the population of beluga, as well as the preservation of natural spawning and juveniles breeding at hatcheries.

In the Danube the release of recruitment size (over 15 cm long) from Romania into the Danube has risen from 12,500 in 2006, to 15,130 in 2007 and 20,000 in 2008 (Suciu pers. comm.).

Iran, in work with the World Bank, are increasing the rate of release of Beluga; in 2003, 6,000 individuals (CWT tagged and visible tagged) were released. The size of the released individuals has been increased from 3-5 g to 10-25 g to increase survival rates (Pourali et al. 2003). Hatchery experts (which are state owned) are given financial incentives upon the delivery of individuals ready to be released. Iran has also developed beluga farming to supply meat and caviar production to minimize the impact to the wild population (Pourkazemi pers. comm.).

The species is not fully protected in any range state, though fishing licences are required in most countries and Iran has banned private sturgeon fisheries. Overall however, enforcement measures seem to be lacking. In 1996, fishing in the open sea for the species was banned through an agreement between the countries bordering the Caspian Sea. Artificial spawning grounds have been attempted below Volgograd dam, which has shown some success (Ruban pers. comm.). In the Sea of Azov commercial fishing was banned in 1986.

Gene banks, DNA and tissue cryopreservation exists in Iran and Russia.

Azerbaijan have voluntarily proposed a zero quota for Caviar export for 2009 to CITES.

Range states are also encouraged to provide protection to the species spawning and feeding grounds.

rationale: The species is known from five streams on the Crimea with an extent of occurrence of less than 1,000 km² (area of occupancy of spawning sites estimated to be less than 500 km²). It is threatened by pollution (Salgir stream), water abstraction (Alma, Chornaya, Kacha) and river regulation (Chornaya). It's presence in Salgir needs to be confirmed, it is rare in Kacha and Chornaya streams, almost extirpated in Alma but still abundant in the Bel Bek stream.
habitat:
Habitat:
Lower and middle parts of streams and estuaries. In estuaries, lives close to surface. Migrates to upper reaches of streams in piedmont and montane zones. Spawns in riffles with heavy current on gravel bottom.

Biology:
Lives up to five years. Spawns for the first time at three years. Spawns in June-July. Forages in small stream estuaries and migrates upstream to spawn. Some juveniles forage in lower part of streams. Feeds on drifting and terrestrial insects and zooplankton. Regularly hybridizes with Squalius cephalus.
threats: It is threatened by pollution (Salgir stream), water abstraction (Alma, Chornaya, Kacha) and river regulation (Chornaya). The level of drought is predicted to increase in severity due to climate change.
population: It's presence in Salgir needs to be confirmed, it is rare in Kacha and Chornaya streams, almost extirpated in Almastill but still abundant in the Bel Bek stream.
range: The species is known from five streams on the Crimea; Salgir, Alma, Chornya, Bel Bek and Kacha.
conservationActions: No information.

rationale: Common in England, very few fragmented populations in Belgium and France, several of them threatened by pollution, water abstraction and alteration of river morphology.
habitat:
Habitat:
Small streams to medium-sized rivers.

Biology:
Lives up to six years. Spawns for the first time at one year. Spawns in March-April. Females spawn once a year in Belgium; up to four times, in February-early July, in stream Bere (southern England). Most individuals spawn 2-3 seasons. They lay adhesive eggs in a compact clutch on ceiling of small cavities in gravel or rock bottom. Males guard eggs until hatching. Males may guard egg clutches of several females. Feeds on a wide variety of benthic invertebrates.
threats: Pollution, water abstraction and alteration of river morphology.
population: Abundant.
range: Great Britain; Atlantic drainages from Garonne (tributaries draining from Massif Central) to Scheldt [French: Escaut] in France and Belgium. Lower, middle and northern upper Rhine mainstream in Germany and the Netherlands, reaching upriver (southward) to Karlsruhe. Also in rivers Mosel and Sieg in Germany. Might also be present in other major Rhine tributaries, the French stretch of the upper Rhine and the lower Meuse.
conservationActions: No information.

rationale: The species is widespread. Even though the species has many threats, including water abstraction, dams and channelization of lower courses of rivers, it is not believed that these  will cause the species to meet any of the criteria for a threatened or Near Threatened Category at present.
habitat:
Habitat:
Rivulets and streams 3-10 m wide and less than 1 m deep in foothills and plains, sometimes in channels. Usually on gravel, rarely on sand bottom. Usually along steep banks.

Biology:
Spawns in July-August.
threats: Water abstraction in particular in Iran, dams, channelization of the lower courses and drought (predicted to increase in severity due to climate change).
population: No information.
range: Caspian basin: From Kuma, south to lower courses of Iranian costal drainages to Gorgan Bay.
conservationActions: No information.

rationale: Known from lowland rivers of the Don drainage where it is locally threatened by pollution and river engineering. The species most likely declined due to construction of large reservoirs on Don in mid 20th century but it is suspected to have stabilised at a moderate level in recent times. The species does not qualify for a threatened or Near Threatened category.
habitat:
Habitat:
Bottom of moderately flowing lowland rivers, prefers sand bottom.

Biology:
Lives up to five years. Spawns for the first time at two years. Females spawn up to four times during a season at about two-week intervals in May-July. Nocturnal, benthic, feeds on insect larvae and other large benthic invertebrates.
threats: Locally threatened by pollution and river channelization.
population: Abundant, even in the large resevoirs.
range: Lowland river of the Don drainage.
conservationActions: No information.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable in view of the small estimated area occupied by viable populations (estimated at less than 500 sq km; total occupied area may be substantially larger), severely fragmented distribution, and continuing decline in populations and area and quality of habitat. This species has undergone a major, long-term decline. Most of the decline occurred more than 10 years or three generations ago.
habitat: This species usually occurs in or near quiet permanent water of streams, marshes, ponds, lakes, and other quiet bodies of water. In summer, frogs estivate in small mammal burrows, leaf litter, or other moist sites in or near (within a few hundred feet of) riparian areas (Rathbun et al. 1993, cited by USFWS 1994; USFWS 1996). Individuals may range far from water along riparian corridors and in damp thickets and forests. Breeding occurs in permanent or seasonal water of ponds, marshes, or quiet stream pools, sometimes in lakes (Fellers, in Jones et al. 2005); eggs often are attached to emergent vegetation, float at surface (Hayes and Miyamoto 1984).
threats:
Factors contributing to the decline include wetland destruction and degradation/fragmentation, urbanization, residential development, reservoir construction, stream channelization, livestock grazing of riparian vegetation, off-road vehicle activity, drought, overharvesting, and exotic fishes (bass, mosquitofish) and possibly bullfrogs (Kiesecker and Blaustein 1998; USFWS 1994, 1996, 2000; Adams 1999, 2000; Lawler et al. 1999; Cook and Jennings 2001; Kiesecker, Blaustein and Miller 2001a; Cook 2002). An important threat is the loss of wetlands in the Willamette Valley (Oregon) and Puget Lowlands (Washington). Conversion of habitat to more permanent ponds is an important threat (as this allows breeding waters to be invaded by non-native predators).

Declines in the red-legged frog complex also have been attributed to global warming, UV-B radiation (Belden and Blaustein 2002), airborne contaminants (pesticide drift), and disease (see Davidson et al. 2001). Davidson et al. (2002) found support for the negative impact of wind-borne agrochemicals and weaker evidence for the widespread impact of habitat destruction and UV-B radiation; evidence did not support the hypothesis that declines have been caused by climate change.
population:
Number of distinct occurrences (subpopulations) is unknown but probably is at least several dozen. According to USFWS (2000), the species occurs in about 238 streams or drainages.

In the mid-1990s, most of the occupied habitat was in Monterey, San Luis Obispo, and Santa Barbara counties; the species occurred in only 5 sites south of the Tehachapi Mountains (80+ historic sites) (USFWS 1996) Aggregations including more than 350 adults were known only from Pescadero Marsh Natural Preserve in coastal San Mateo County, Point Reyes National Seashore in Marin County, and Rancho San Carlos in Monterey County (USFWS 1996). More than 120 breeding sites exist in Marin County (Fellers, in Lannoo 2005).

In California, south of Los Angeles, a single population is known from the Santa Rosa Plateau in Riverside County (Shaffer et al. 2004). Only two populations are known to exist south of Santa Barabra (Fellers, in Lannoo 2005).

In the Sierra Nevada, Rana draytonii is now represented by only about a half dozen populations, only one of which is known to have more than 10 breeding adults (Shaffer et al. 2004).

Total adult population size is unknown but undoubtedly exceeds 10,000. The species is still locally abundant in portions of the San Francisco Bay area and the central coast (USFWS 2000). Breeding sites in Marin County include several thousand adults (Fellers, in Lannoo 2005).

Over the long term, extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, number of subpopulations, and population size have undergone a major decline. The species has been extirpated from much of its former range in California (Hayes and Jennings 1988, Shaffer et al. 2004). Range has been reduced by 70% (USFWS 1996, 2000). Currently, area of occupancy, number of subpopulations, and population size probabaly are still declining, but the rate of decline is unknown.
range: Native historical range extended from southern Mendocino County in northwestern California south (primarily west of the Cascade-Sierra crest) to northwestern Baja California (Shaffer et al. 2004). Historical populations on the floor of the Central Valley may not have persisted due to extensive natural flooding (Fellers, in Lannoo 2005). Range is now much reduced in the Sierra Nevada and in southern California, but the species is still present throughout much of its former range in the central California coast range (Fellers, in Lannoo 2005). This species has been introduced in a few places in Nevada, but the current status of those populations is uncertain (A. Cook, cited by Fellers, in Lannoo 2005). Rana draytonii is still present in Baja California, Mexico (USFWS 2000, Grismer 2002, Shaffer et al. 2004). Elevational range extended from sea level to about 1,500 meters (5,000 feet); usually below 1,200 meters (3,935 feet).
conservationActions: The U.S. Geological Survey has developed a conservation plan for this species, and about 1.7 million hectares were designated as critical habitat for it in California (USFWS 2001). A monitoring and conservation program needs to be implemented in the Mexican portion of the range, which does not include any protected areas.

rationale: Alcichthys elongatus is fairly widespread and common at least in parts of its range, with no known major threats except incidental catch in gill nets over rocky reefs and therefore Least Concern.
habitat: Alcichthys elongatus is a demersal species with a depth range of 15 - 269 m and inhabits temperate waters. It has been observed to aggregate in winter in the Gamov drop-offs in the western part of the Peter the Great Bay (Izmyatinskii 2006). Maximum size about 30 cm; found primarily on rocky reef habitats (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2009).
threats: There are no known threats for Alcichthys elongatus. This species is not targeted directly by any fishery. It is incidentally caught in gill netting on rocky reefs (K. Matsuura pers.comm. 2009). The Sea of Japan and Sea of Okhotsk are subject to heavy shipping traffic and its associated threats: bilge and ballast water, fuel and oil leaks, and anti-fouling chemicals; it is unknown if this species is affected by these threats.
population: It has been observed to aggregate in winter in the Gamov drop-offs in the western part of the Peter the Great Bay (Izmyatinskii 2006).  Common around Hokkaido (K. Matsuura pers.comm. 2009).
range: The distribution of Alcichthys elongatus ranges from the Iwate and Shimane Prefectures of Japan, northwards, in both the Sea of Japan and the Sea of Okhotsk.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Alcichthys elongatus, however its distribution may coincide with a number of marine protected areas.

rationale: Callionymus comptus has been assessed as Vulnerable under criterion B1ab(iii). Its distribution is extremely patchy and its extent of occurrence is estimated to be less than 20,000 km². This species has been threatened by coral reef degradation and this threat is likely to continue in the future. Research into potential conservation measures for this species is needed.
habitat: Callionymus comptus is restricted to sand patches on reef crests and lagoon areas, where it buries itself in clean sand. This benthopelagic species is found at depths of 3-28 m.
threats: Callionymus comptus is associated with coral reef habitats. The coral reefs of Hawaii have been degraded due to pollution, development and dredging. The most significant threats to the reefs are coral bleaching and disease, and invasive alien species (Friedlander et al. 2004). It is predicted that Hawaii's reefs will continue to be degraded in future as human pressures increase, but the rate of decline can be reduced if there is effective protection and management (Friedlander et al. 2004).
population: This species is rare (R. Fricke pers. comm. 2008).
range: Callionymus comptus is known only from the Hawaiian Islands. The distribution of this species is severely fragmented, because very few areas in the Hawaiian Islands meet its habitat requirements (R. Fricke pers. comm. 2008). It is estimated that the total range area for this species is less than 20,000 km².
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Callionymus comptus. However, the distribution of this species may fall within several designated marine protected areas (MPAs) in the Hawaiian Islands.

Monitoring of this species and its threats should be undertaken to accurately determine the impact of coral reef degradation on the population in the future. Research is also needed on species-specific conservation measures for this species, to try to prevent further negative impacts on the population of C. comptus.

rationale: Artedielloides auriculatus has been assessed as Near Threatened. It is only found in Peter the Great Bay (one single location) and the habitat in which this species is found is under a number of serious threats. However, the severity of the threats are unclear. Further research on the ecology, potential threats and population numbers of this species is needed to determine if it qualifies for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: Artedielloides auriculatus is a benthic species found over sand and mud substrates at a depth range of 29-70 m.
threats:
This species is of no commercial interest to fisheries. Due to its small size, it is unlikely to be taken in significant quantities as by-catch.

The marine ecosystem in which this species is found, has suffered from intense shipping traffic and its associated threats including: bilge and ballast water, oil and fuel leaks, and anti-fouling chemicals. Peter the Great Bay is also known for high levels of radionuclides in the sediments and red tides.
population: There is no population information available for Artedielloides auriculatus.
range: Artedielloides auriculatus is found in Peter the Great Bay, an inlet into the Sea of Japan, Russia.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Artedielloides auriculatus.

Further research on the population trends, ecology, and potential threat processes of this species is needed as little information is available.

rationale: Bathymaster derjugini has been assessed as Data Deficient. This species does not have a broad geographic range and so without fully understanding what threats it faces, it is difficult to determine on what scale it is being impacted. This species warrants further r
habitat: Bathymaster derjugini is a demersal species that has a depth range of 0 - 65 m. It inhabits shallow water in the upper reaches of the sublittoral zone (Cook et al. 1999) and rocky shore areas.
threats: Due to the coastal nature of this species, it may be impacted by coastal development and pollution, and some areas in which it is found is subject to heavy shipping traffic and threats associated with this such as bilge and ballast water and fuel dumping. It is not known how this species is being impacted by these threats.
population:
There is no population information available for Bathymaster derjugini.

In the central east Pacific, the larvae of this family were the most abundant comprising 94.6% of the sample (Franco-Gordo et al. 2001).
range: Bathymaster derjugini is distributed from the Kuril Islands and Tartar Strait, to Peter the Great Bay, Russia.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Bathymaster derjugini. However the distribution of this species may fall within several designated marine protected areas.

Further research is needed on the threats faced by this species.

rationale: The species is recorded from Sittwe and Kayin State in Myanmar, and  from locations in northeastern India (from the Kaladan River and tributaries). Whilst its habitat within India is known to be impacted by deforestation and siltation, little is known of  its habitat within Myanmar, though gas and river transport development projects may impact upon the species habitat. The species is at present assessed as Data Deficient but further information is needed on the species' full distribution, especially within Myanmar and the impact of known threats, and should be reassessed when this becomes available through additional expert survey.
habitat: The species inhabits moderate to fast flowing mountain streams and rivers with rocky bed.
threats:
Hill streams are threatened by sedimentation due to deforestation and agricultural practices resulting in continuing decline in the quality of habitat.

The Kaladyne River is subject to development as part of joint Indo-Myanmar project to develop river transport links to the Myanmar port of Sitwe. In addition, the impact of the Shwe Gas Project on the river and its habitats requires further study.
population: Talwar and Jhingran (1991) considered it a rare species. Further survey work is needed to determine whether or not this species is experiencing a decline, or is undergoing extreme population fluctuations.
range: The species is recorded from Sittwe (formerly Akyab) and in Tandaung Township, Sittaung River Drainage (C. Ferraris, NMNH), Myanmar, and from locations in northeastern India (Kolodyne (Kaladan) and Mat (a tributary of the Koladyne) Rivers of Mizoram) The species is apparently restricted to the Koladyne River and its tributaries; records from Arunachal Pradesh (two records in the Brahmaputra drainage; Centre for Environmental Management and Participatory Development, 2009) most likely refer to S. semiplotus (V. Waikhom, pers. comm., 2010).
useTrade: This rare species attains a length of about 20 cm; of no interest to fisheries (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
conservationActions: Research on distribution, biology, habitat use, population, trends and threats are needed.

rationale: This species is assessed as Vulnerable due to its restricted distribution at one location. This makes the species very vulnerable to any potential threats, which would rapidly affect all the individuals in the population. D. brieni may be currently threatened by a decline in habitat degradation, caused by deforestation and pollution in the surrounding area.
habitat: D. brieni is a demersal species that lives in the sand.
threats: Malebo Pool faces some environmental threat. Urbanisation at the pool forms a problem in the region through sewage cast and lead toxicity, mainly coming from car oil and a lot of boat traffic. There is still a lot of fish, but it has been reported that the general size of different species is getting smaller and smaller. Much of the area became deforested following development of the railway along the Lower Congo in the early 1900s but gallery forests still line sections of the river through the Lower Congo (Stiassny 2003). However, the effect of deforestation on D. brieni is not known.
population: The population trend and numbers are unknown and further research is required for this species.
range: This species is known only form its type locality (a channel in front of the refuge Jipo) in Malebo Pool, a large riverine lake shared by the Congo and the Democratic Republic of Congo, formed by the widening of the Congo River (Roberts 2003).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures or actions known. Monitoring of the population and the habitat would be beneficial.

rationale: Although there are threats known in the species distribution area, the species is listed Least Concern because of its relatively broad expected distribution.
habitat: N. gracillis is a pelagic species.
threats: Artisanal, but very intensive diamond mining is a very important threat in small rivers in the Kasai region. The sand from digging in the river and the river beds causes sedimentation. Urbanisation at Pool Malebo (Stanley Pool) forms a problem in the region through sewage cast and lead toxicity, mainly coming from car oil and a lot of boat traffic.
population: Currently, there is a lack of detailed population numbers and the global trend is unknown.
range: Nannocharax gracilis is known from Pool Malebo (Stanley Pool) and from the central Congo River basin. It is expected to be more widespread in the Central Congo basin than currently known.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures or actions known.

rationale: This species is considered to be endemic to the Ayeyarwady River delta in Myanmar, although it is only known from the vicinity of Maubin and has an estimated area of occupancy of less than 500 km²<sup></sup>. It is threatened by extensive habitat decline throughout its restricted range due human development, pollution and dredging. It is listed as Endangered. There is very little information on the distribution, ecology and threats to this species and further study is recommended.
habitat: The specimens were taken from a freshwater swamp forest habitat but little is known about the habitat and biology of this species (Murphy 2007).
threats: This species currently inhabits a severely degraded habitat. The sedimentation rate of the Ayeyarwady River is extremely high due to continued deforestation occurring upstream (Murphy 2007). There is also pollution and dredging activities in the river. The Ayeyarwady River delta is very densely populated which has contributed to ongoing urban and coastal development and modification of river drainages.
population: There is no information available on the abundance of this species, but it is thought to be uncommon.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of Maubin, Ayeyarwady Division, Myanmar. Information for this species is from nine specimens collected from this location.
